column2: Commissioner Moscovici's remarks at the Eurogroup press conference

column3:
Merci Jeroen. 

J’ai effectivement informé l’Eurogroupe cet après-midi de l’état des discussions entre les institutions et la Grèce.

J’étais la semaine dernière à Athènes où j’ai eu des discussions constructives et utiles avec les autorités, dont le premier ministre Alexis Tsipras et Euclid Tsakalotos, que nous avons aussi eu le plaisir d’entendre aujourd’hui. 

Je veux souligner à mon tour que la coopération avec les autorités grecques est vraiment bonne, qu'elle est tout à fait à la hauteur de celle que nous avons eue dans le passé avec les autres pays sous programme et qu'il y a une démarche coopérative et que nos équipes travaillent jour et nuit – et quand je dis jour et nuit, je ne n’exagère pas – pour aboutir à un accord sur les points encore ouverts. 

Je veux dire trois choses. 

La première, c’est que la quantité de mesures qu’il est prévu d’adopter pendant les premiers mois de ce programme est très importante et que celles qui ont déjà été adoptées sont loin d'être négligeables

La deuxième, c’est qu’une grande majorité des milestones dont on discute actuellement a déjà été réalisée ou est en cours de finalisation, j'ai pu expliquer que si on prenait déjà ce qui était réalisé ou en cours de finalisation, cela représentait tout de même 80 % de l'ensemble et il y a encore une dizaine de % qui sont dans la bonne voie. Donc, nous avons fait des progrès incontestables et je crois que l'état d'esprit général était pour le constater et pour souhaiter que cela avance et cela avance dans la bonne direction. 

Il reste évidemment certains points encore à clôturer et il faudra que tout le monde fasse un dernier effort pour atteindre cet objectif dans les prochains jours. 

Jeroen a été très précis sur la question première qui est la question de la recapitalisation des banques, il y en a une autre qui est liée, c'est la question des crédits non-performants, qui est essentielle pour faire en sorte que le secteur bancaire soit solide et pour permettre que le crédit abonde l'économie réelle.

C'est un problème et un défi qui est très important et pas seulement pour la Grèce, mais aussi pour d'autres pays dans l'Union européenne et la zone euro.

Un aspect particulier, c'est la loi sur les foreclosures sur laquelle il y a encore des discussions assez intenses qui se déroulent et nous devons trouver là un équilibre, une solution équilibrée qui protège les plus vulnérables, car c'est notre intention commune, il ne peut pas y avoir des gens qui se retrouvent sans toit et en même temps nous devons éviter que certains abusent des protections qui sont en place et c'est la raison pour laquelle nous cherchons une solution. Nous travaillons et nous continuons à travailler.

Je suis confiant dans le fait qu'on puisse trouver une solution acceptable pour tous et qui soit surtout efficace. Et ces deux questions, recapitalisation des banques et foreclosure legislation sont évidemment étroitement liées.

Sur le plan de la situation économique et budgétaire, j'ai profité de l'occasion d'aujourd'hui pour présenter à nos collègues les prévisions d'automne de la Commission européenne qui avaient déjà été développées la semaine dernière et j'ai insisté sur l'aspect zone euro.

As you are aware, the forecast sees the moderate recovery of the euro area and the EU continuing, despite slower growth in emerging market economies and world trade.

I just record the figures. The euro area economy is expected to grow by 1.6% this year and then by 1.8% in 2016 and 1.9% in 2017. 

The growth outlook continues to benefit from tailwinds such as low oil prices, QE and, to some extent, the euro’s exchange rate, which is the consequence of the accommodative ECB monetary policy  as well as the broadly neutral fiscal stance, which should go on.

I emphasised that domestic demand is projected to strengthen on the back of rising disposable income, improving employment and the gradual fading of legacy problems such as deleveraging and NPLs, while investment should also progressively pick up.

Finally, I pointed out that an early simulation of the impact of the refugee influx suggests that the overall economic effects should be small but positive, although how positive depends on how well the new arrivals can be integrated into the workforce.

As Jeroen said on a third point, we had a first but quite extensive orientation debate today on the proposals which the Commission put forward to implement the recommendations set out in the Five Presidents’ Report on completing Europe’s Economic and Monetary Union. 

The Commission looks forward to continuing this discussion over the coming months. We are already presenting some proposals and we are going to present more.

One word about Spain:

I informed the Eurogroup today of the main findings of the 4th post-programme surveillance mission to Spain, which the Commission carried out together with the ECB and the ESM.

The review report, which we will finalise in the coming weeks, makes a broad assessment of Spain’s economic and financial situation and fulfils the specific monitoring requirement of Spain’s macroeconomic imbalances under the Macroeconomic Imbalances Procedure (MIP).

Spain’s economy, labour market, current account and banking sector have all improved significantly, with the help of substantial reforms. GDP growth this year is expected to be 3.1%, significantly above than the euro area average, and private sector debt levels continue to come down in an orderly fashion.

Nevertheless, I also insisted on the fact that challenges remain and sound public finances and further reforms will be needed to consolidate Spain’s recent progress but this progress is of course undoubtable.

We also agreed with Jeroen that on basis of the forecast we will be able to adopt the opinion on the draft budgetary plans, which we do not talk about today, so that we have a discussion in a special Eurogroup when the time comes.

column1: Commissioner Moscovici presents the 2015 Autumn Economic Forecast,05-11-2015,European Commission,European Commission,2614,"                                   European Commission - Speech - [Check Against Delivery]        Commissioner Moscovici presents the 2015 Autumn Economic Forecast   Brussels, 5 November 2015            The slides of the presentation can be found here.[slide 1]: Introduction slideWelcome to this presentation of the autumn economic forecast of the European Commission in 2015.I basically three messages to passing today. The first is that the economic recovery will continue in 2016 and 2017, with slightly different probably engines. The second is that the improvement of the budgetary situation of Member States is continuing, including debt from 2016. Finally, and this is new for the recommendation for the eurozone we adopt mi -November, we analyze the convergence between countries in the euro zone, which remains insufficient.[slide 2]: Moderate recovery continues Let's start with the economic recovery in the euro area and throughout the European Union has entered its third year and is expected to continue.Although more moderate than in the past, the recovery has so far resisted the face of recent uncertainties. The effects of the slowdown in emerging markets and the significant drop in international trade in recent months, however, should begin to be felt. I'll come back. Moreover, the risks to growth have clearly increased due to this degradation exterierur environment, including the international geostrategic situation. Specifically, in the euro area, GDP should grow by 1.6% in 2015, 1.8% in 2016 and 1.9% in 2017. For the 28, we expect growth of 1.9% in 2015 , 2.0% in 2016 and 2.1% in 2017.[Slide 3]: Tailwinds still supporting growthAs we predicted in the spring, the economic recovery in the euro area this year was driven by a combination of factors, including weak oil prices and the exchange rate of the euro relatively low when compared last year. This is true in our autumn forecast. First, after rebounding to around $ 60 a barrel in the spring, the Brent barrel of oil is around $ 48 currently. Given these developments, our oil price assumptions for 2015 and 2016 have been revised downwards compared with the spring forecast. In 2017, prices should also remain low. The oil prices fall significantly reduced energy costs for companies and households, allowing an increase in profit margins and household purchasing power.Second, the depreciation of the euro was boosted by the quantitative easing ECB decision in January 2015. She had a positive impact for exporters in the euro area and allowed them to gain market share. The exchange rate of the euro should continue to support short-term economic recovery.Finally, the ECB's quantitative easing program has meanwhile improved financing conditions in the euro area and the credit cost is observed that remains low for households and businesses. The annual credit growth in the euro area for business is also turned positive since the summer, for the first time since the spring of 2012, while the additional liquidity provided by the ECB's program encourages banks to lend more.[Slide 4] Increased, but temporary, global headwindsThe outlook for global growth and world trade have deteriorated since the spring. This is mainly due to a larger than expected slowdown in emerging markets and faster adjustment in China. Motor tipping the global growth of emerging countries to advanced economies is well illustrated in the graph behind me. We project economic growth in China of 6.8% in 2015 and 6.2% in 2017. This ""landing smoothly"" scenario assumes that economic rebalancing in China - a growth based mainly on investment to more balanced growth with a major role for the consumer - is happening without major frictions. The slowdown in emerging countries, however, should give way to a gradual rebound in growth from 2016. World growth (outside the EU) and should slow from 3.7% in 2014 to 3.3% this year, before strengthening gradually and reach 3.8% in 2016 and 4% in 2017. This gradual strengthening global growth and world trade should support external demand for European exports, although less than was expected in the spring.[Slide 5] Other factors are set to support growthI would like now to turn to an interesting economic development for the years to come. The strength of these tailwinds is set to gradually fade and other factors should assume a larger role in driving the recovery in Europe in 2016 and 2017:First, the fruits of recent structural reforms – including of labour and product markets and tax systems – in some Member States should become increasingly tangible. Second, while the pressure to reduce debt remains high in some Member States, it should gradually become less of a constraint on companies' and households' spending.Third, after several years of fiscal consolidation, fiscal policy is set to remain broadly neutral – in other words, neither tightening nor loosening – while monetary policy is expected to remain highly accommodative.[Slide 5b] Surge in refugees is good for growthAnother important development since our last forecast is the influx as refugees. Our forecast makes a first preliminary assessment of the economic impact of this influx, based on several assumptions that would need to be checked against reality in the months to come. It takes into account additional public expenditure and additional labour supply from recognised refugees who will gain the right to work. The impact on economic growth would be small but positive for the EU as a whole, raising GDP by 0.2-0.3% by 2017. The impact could, however, be more significant for individual countries, in particular for destination countries. The expected rise in the labour force over the forecast horizon, could also translate into additional employment but this will crucially depend on efforts to integrate the refugees. The box on page 48 of the forecast document gives further details, also on the underlying assumptions of the calculations.[Slide 6] Growth map 2016Let me now turn to our growth map of Europe for 2016. Economic activity should be on the rise in nearly all Member States next year, with an acceleration expected in 2017 in most of them. Among the largest EU economies, GDP growth in 2016 is expected to be above the EU average (of 2.0%) in Poland at 3.5%, Spain at 2.7%, the UK at 2.4% and the Netherlands at 2.1%. Economic growth in Germany at 1.9% will be just above the euro-area average (1.8%). The robust labour market, favourable financing conditions and additional public spending to host and integrate the large number of asylum seekers will contribute to growth. In Italy, growth is expected to pick up to 1.5% in 2016, driven by domestic demand. En France, la croissance du PIB devrait atteindre 1,4% en 2016, grâce à une consommation des ménages toujours robuste et la reprise de l'investissement. Among other Member States, Ireland and Romania are set to grow at above 4%, while Latvia, Luxembourg and Malta are projected to grow at 3% or above. Finally, as regards the two Member States in economic adjustment programmes, Cyprus’ economy is expected to grow by 1.2% this year and 1.4% next year, driven by stronger private demand. Greece is projected to slip back into recession in 2015 with GDP set to contract by 1.4% – though this is almost one percentage point better than projected in August, when the baseline for the ESM programme was set – and by 1.3% in 2016. As I indicated in Athens yesterday, growth should return in the second half of next year to reach 2.7% in 2017 as the implementation of the programme enables a return of confidence and investment.[Slide 7] Private consumption remains the main growth engineTurning now to the main components of growth, private consumption has been fuelling the pick-up in domestic demand. It is expected to maintain its growth momentum in the near term. Supporting this positive development are the continued rise in nominal incomes and the boost to purchasing power from lower energy prices. In 2016 and 2017, improving labour market conditions and still relatively low consumer price inflation should further support private consumption growth.[slide 8]: Improving labour market conditionsLabour market conditions continue to improve slowly but steadily given the rising economic activity. The unemployment rate is expected to decline gradually, but it remains too high and it varies greatly across Member States. Employment is expected to grow by about 1% over the forecast horizon in both the euro area and the EU. This pace of job creation and of economic growth looks unlikely to reduce unemployment rates to below pre-crisis levels. Countries which have implemented labour market reforms should see further gains in employment. These include Greece, Italy, Spain and Portugal. In 2016, unemployment is expected to fall to 10.6% in the euro area and 9.2% in the EU, and to decline further in 2017.[slide 9]: Low inflation in the euro area is supporting purchasing powerThis year, inflation is expected to remain close to zero, mostly because of the renewed fall in energy and commodity prices. This is having a positive impact on households' purchasing power. In contrast, core inflation – that is, without the more volatile energy and food price components – is showing some signs of strengthening, reflecting the increase in private consumption. Over the forecast horizon, the recovery in oil prices along with wage increases should push prices further up. As a result, annual inflation in the euro area is expected to rise from 0.1% this year to 1.0 % next year, and to pick up to 1.6% in 2017, which is of course a welcome development as it reflects a normalisation of economic conditions.[slide 10]: Investment recovery fragile – but set to strengthenInvestment growth, though strengthening, remains weak when compared to past recoveries as you can see on this graph. Subdued demand expectations, high uncertainty and the persistent need to reduce debt in some Member States are still weighing on investment decisions. Construction investment should recover, thanks to the rise in households' real disposable income as well as easier access to financing. Equipment investment is supported by low oil prices and improved profit margins as well as low financing costs, and it is forecast to strengthen along with the brighter outlook in global demand in 2017.[slide 11]: Risks to the growth outlookTo conclude on the growth perspective, I would like to mention some of the risks. The balance of risks to the growth outlook has shifted to the downside as external risks have increased. In particular, the negative impact of the weakness in some emerging market economies could turn out to be larger than envisaged, and notably a ""hard landing"" in China would be detrimental. Financial market volatility could increase given the uncertainty surrounding the normalisation of monetary policy in the US with potential consequences on asset prices and capital flows. Geopolitical tensions are keeping uncertainty at high levels and could become a larger impediment to investment spending than currently expected. Legacies from the crisis may continue to weigh more heavily on investment activity than expected, and fading tailwinds could not be replaced by more endogenous growth drivers.But there are also upside risks, namely: Stronger or more persistent tailwinds would have a positive impact on economic growth. A stronger-than-expected revival in global growth dynamics and world trade could push demand for European exports more than expected. A more favourable impact from already-implemented and future structural reforms could also provide additional stimuli to economic growth. [slide 12]: Budgetary outlook for 2016The second important message coming out of these forecasts is the improving fiscal outlook, as the reduction in general government deficits continues: In the euro area, the deficit is forecast to stand at 2% of GDP in 2015 and to decline to 1.8% in 2016 and 1.5% in 2017. In the EU as a whole, the deficit is forecast at 2.5% of GDP in 2015 and to decline to 2% next year and 1.6% in 2017.In most Member States, deficit ratios are projected to fall in 2015 and to continue on this path in 2016 and 2017. In the euro area, we expect only France, Spain and Greece to have deficits above the 3% of GDP threshold in 2016. The fiscal policy stance is expected to be broadly neutral in the euro area in 2015 and 2016, as the changes to the structural balance should be broadly nil in both years. The debt-to-GDP ratio is forecast to decline as of this year from the peak reached in 2014, and to reach 91.3% in the euro area and 85.8% in the EU in 2017. Our forecast takes into account revenue and expenditure trends and the inclusion of measures that were incorporated in the Draft Budgetary Plans for 2016, as submitted by euro-area Member States to the Commission by 15 October 2015. The forecast for 2017 rests on a no-policy-change assumption, since policy measures for that years have in most cases still to be specified by national authorities. [slide 13]: Convergence in the euro areaFinally, and this would be my third message today, I would like to conclude with a few remarks on the issue of convergence in the euro area. In our Communication on steps towards completing the Economic and Monetary Union last month, we committed to work to facilitate convergence between euro area Member States. Looking at our Autumn Forecast, the picture so far is mixed.First, potential growth paths are re-converging – but only very slowly. Some countries are catching up thanks to the implementation of structural reforms, but a timely implementation of these reforms is needed in order to improve the efficiency of labour- and product markets and further increase growth potential.Second, labour-market conditions are improving – but disparities remain high. Unemployment is receding in most Member States but will still be 25.8% in Greece and 20.5% in Spain compared with 4.9% in Germany in 2016.Third, the debt-to-GDP ratio has peaked in 2014 in the euro area as a whole – but in some Member States it is still expected to increase next year: among others, in Greece, France, Spain and Belgium. Finally, as regards the current account balance, former deficit countries have adjusted – while, overall, large savings and investment imbalances remain.As a result, the current-account surplus reaches a historically high level in the euro area. These positions are not expected to change significantly over the forecast horizon.[Slide 14] Growth map 2016 To sum up, these are my key takeaways from this year's Autumn Forecast:The European economy remains on recovery course.Unemployment will continue to fall while remaining too high in many countries.The recovery is still supported by well-known tailwinds, including low oil prices which are set to persist into 2016.Other positive factors are increasingly taking over, such as the impact of structural reforms.We project a soft landing for the Chinese economy and a rebound in other emerging economies' growth from 2016.Inflation will gradually increase from its current very low level while remaining moderate.Overall deficit and debt levels in the EU will decline.Finally, further efforts are needed to support convergence in the euro area.Today's forecast will provide the basis for a number of policy decisions to be taken over the next couple of weeks, notably the Commission’s Opinions on the euro area Member States’ Draft Budgetary Plans. The forecast will also feed into the preparation of the Annual Growth Survey and the Alert Mechanism Report on Macroeconomic Imbalances, which we will also be presenting later this month as we kick off the next European Semester of economic policy coordination.If you would like to know about our policy conclusions deriving from today’s figures, I must therefore invite you to have a little more patience.On our Autumn Forecast itself, I am happy to now take your questions. column2: Commissioner Moscovici presents the 2015 Autumn Economic Forecast

column3:
The slides of the presentation can be found

here

.

[slide 1]: Introduction slide

Bienvenue à cette présentation des prévisions économiques d'automne 2015 de la Commission européenne.

J’ai essentiellement trois messages à passer aujourd’hui. Le premier, c’est que la reprise économique va continuer en 2016 et 2017, avec des moteurs sans doute un peu différents. Le second c’est que l’amélioration de la situation budgétaire des Etats membres se poursuit, y compris pour la dette à partir de 2016. Enfin, et c’est une nouveauté en vue de la recommandation pour la zone euro que nous adopterons mi-novembre, nous analysons la convergence entre pays de la zone euro, qui reste insuffisante.

[slide 2]: Moderate recovery continues

Commençons donc par la reprise économique dans la zone euro et dans l’ensemble de l'Union européenne qui est entrée dans sa troisième année consécutive et devrait se poursuivre.

Bien que plus modérée que par le passé, la reprise a jusqu'à présent résisté face aux récentes incertitudes. Les effets du ralentissement des marchés émergents et de l'importante chute du commerce international de ces derniers mois devraient cependant commencer à se faire ressentir. Je vais y revenir. De plus, les risques pesant sur la croissance ont clairement augmenté du fait de cette dégradation de l'environnement exterierur, y compris de la situation géostratégique international. Concrètement, dans la zone euro, le PIB devrait croître de 1,6% en 2015, de 1,8% en 2016 et de 1,9% en 2017. Pour les 28, nous prévoyons une croissance de 1,9% en 2015, de 2,0% en 2016 et de 2,1% en 2017.

[Slide 3]: Tailwinds still supporting growth

Comme nous l'avions prévu au printemps, la reprise économique de la zone euro cette année a été portée par une combinaison de facteurs, parmi lesquels la faiblesse des prix du pétrole et un taux de change de l'euro relativement bas si on le compare à l'année dernière. Ceci reste vrai dans nos prévisions d’automne. Premièrement, après un rebond aux alentours de 60$ le baril au printemps, le cours du baril de pétrole Brent se situe environ à 48$ actuellement. Compte tenu de ces développements, nos hypothèses de prix du pétrole pour 2015 et 2016 ont été revues à la baisse par rapport aux prévisions de printemps. En 2017, les prix devraient également rester faibles. La chute des prix du pétrole a considérablement réduit les coûts énergétiques pour les entreprises et les ménages, permettant un accroissement des marges bénéficiaires des entreprises et du pouvoir d'achat des ménages.

Deuxièmement, la dépréciation de l'euro a été amplifiée par la décision d'assouplissement quantitatif de la BCE en janvier 2015. Elle a eu un impact positif pour les exportateurs de la zone euro et leur a permis de gagner des parts de marché. Le taux de change de l'euro devrait continuer à soutenir la reprise économique à court terme.

Enfin, le programme d'assouplissement quantitatif de la BCE a quant à lui permis d'améliorer les conditions de financement dans la zone euro et l'on observe un coût du crédit qui reste bas pour les ménages et les entreprises. La croissance annuelle du crédit dans la zone euro pour les entreprises est d'ailleurs redevenue positive depuis l'été, pour la première fois depuis le printemps de 2012, alors que la liquidité supplémentaire fournie par le programme de la BCE incite les banques à prêter davantage.

[Slide 4] Increased, but temporary, global headwinds

Les perspectives pour la croissance mondiale et les échanges commerciaux mondiaux se sont considérablement détériorées depuis le printemps. Cela est principalement dû à un ralentissement économique plus important qu'escompté dans les pays émergents et un ajustement plus rapide en Chine. Le basculement du moteur de la croissance mondiale des pays émergents vers les économies avancées est bien illustré sur le graphique derrière moi. Nous projetons une croissance économique en Chine de 6.8% en 2015 et 6.2% en 2017. Ce scénario ""d'atterrissage en douceur"" repose sur l'hypothèse que le rééquilibrage économique en Chine – d'une croissance basée surtout sur l'investissement vers une croissance plus équilibrée avec un rôle majeur pour la consommation – se passe sans frictions majeures. Le ralentissement dans les pays émergents devrait cependant laisser place à un rebond progressif de la croissance à partir de 2016. La croissance mondiale (hors Union européenne) devrait ainsi ralentir, passant de 3.7% en 2014 à 3.3% cette année, avant de se renforcer graduellement et d'atteindre 3.8% en 2016 et 4% en 2017. Ce renforcement graduel de la croissance mondiale et du commerce mondial devrait soutenir la demande extérieure des exportations européennes, même si moins que l'on s'attendait au printemps.

[Slide 5] Other factors are set to support growth

I would like now to turn to an interesting economic development for the years to come. The strength of these tailwinds is set to gradually fade and other factors should assume a larger role in driving the recovery in Europe in 2016 and 2017:

First, the fruits of recent structural reforms – including of labour and product markets and tax systems – in some Member States should become increasingly tangible. Second, while the pressure to reduce debt remains high in some Member States, it should gradually become less of a constraint on companies' and households' spending.Third, after several years of fiscal consolidation, fiscal policy is set to remain broadly neutral – in other words, neither tightening nor loosening – while monetary policy is expected to remain highly accommodative.

[Slide 5b] Surge in refugees is good for growth

Another important development since our last forecast is the influx as refugees. Our forecast makes a first preliminary assessment of the economic impact of this influx, based on several assumptions that would need to be checked against reality in the months to come. It takes into account additional public expenditure and additional labour supply from recognised refugees who will gain the right to work. The impact on economic growth would be small but positive for the EU as a whole, raising GDP by 0.2-0.3% by 2017. The impact could, however, be more significant for individual countries, in particular for destination countries. The expected rise in the labour force over the forecast horizon, could also translate into additional employment but this will crucially depend on efforts to integrate the refugees. The box on page 48 of the forecast document gives further details, also on the underlying assumptions of the calculations.

[Slide 6] Growth map 2016

Let me now turn to our growth map of Europe for 2016. Economic activity should be on the rise in nearly all Member States next year, with an acceleration expected in 2017 in most of them. Among the largest EU economies, GDP growth in 2016 is expected to be above the EU average (of 2.0%) in Poland at 3.5%, Spain at 2.7%, the UK at 2.4% and the Netherlands at 2.1%. Economic growth in Germany at 1.9% will be just above the euro-area average (1.8%). The robust labour market, favourable financing conditions and additional public spending to host and integrate the large number of asylum seekers will contribute to growth. In Italy, growth is expected to pick up to 1.5% in 2016, driven by domestic demand. En France, la croissance du PIB devrait atteindre 1,4% en 2016, grâce à une consommation des ménages toujours robuste et la reprise de l'investissement. Among other Member States, Ireland and Romania are set to grow at above 4%, while Latvia, Luxembourg and Malta are projected to grow at 3% or above. Finally, as regards the two Member States in economic adjustment programmes, Cyprus’ economy is expected to grow by 1.2% this year and 1.4% next year, driven by stronger private demand. Greece is projected to slip back into recession in 2015 with GDP set to contract by 1.4% – though this is almost one percentage point better than projected in August, when the baseline for the ESM programme was set – and by 1.3% in 2016. As I indicated in Athens yesterday, growth should return in the second half of next year to reach 2.7% in 2017 as the implementation of the programme enables a return of confidence and investment.

[Slide 7] Private consumption remains the main growth engine

Turning now to the main components of growth, private consumption has been fuelling the pick-up in domestic demand. It is expected to maintain its growth momentum in the near term. Supporting this positive development are the continued rise in nominal incomes and the boost to purchasing power from lower energy prices. In 2016 and 2017, improving labour market conditions and still relatively low consumer price inflation should further support private consumption growth.

[slide 8]: Improving labour market conditions

Labour market conditions continue to improve slowly but steadily given the rising economic activity. The unemployment rate is expected to decline gradually, but it remains too high and it varies greatly across Member States. Employment is expected to grow by about 1% over the forecast horizon in both the euro area and the EU. This pace of job creation and of economic growth looks unlikely to reduce unemployment rates to below pre-crisis levels. Countries which have implemented labour market reforms should see further gains in employment. These include Greece, Italy, Spain and Portugal. In 2016, unemployment is expected to fall to 10.6% in the euro area and 9.2% in the EU, and to decline further in 2017.

[slide 9]: Low inflation in the euro area is supporting purchasing power

This year, inflation is expected to remain close to zero, mostly because of the renewed fall in energy and commodity prices. This is having a positive impact on households' purchasing power. In contrast, core inflation – that is, without the more volatile energy and food price components – is showing some signs of strengthening, reflecting the increase in private consumption. Over the forecast horizon, the recovery in oil prices along with wage increases should push prices further up. As a result, annual inflation in the euro area is expected to rise from 0.1% this year to 1.0 % next year, and to pick up to 1.6% in 2017, which is of course a welcome development as it reflects a normalisation of economic conditions.

[slide 10]: Investment recovery fragile – but set to strengthen

Investment growth, though strengthening, remains weak when compared to past recoveries as you can see on this graph. Subdued demand expectations, high uncertainty and the persistent need to reduce debt in some Member States are still weighing on investment decisions. Construction investment should recover, thanks to the rise in households' real disposable income as well as easier access to financing. Equipment investment is supported by low oil prices and improved profit margins as well as low financing costs, and it is forecast to strengthen along with the brighter outlook in global demand in 2017.

[slide 11]: Risks to the growth outlook

To conclude on the growth perspective, I would like to mention some of the risks. The balance of risks to the growth outlook has shifted to the downside as external risks have increased. In particular, the negative impact of the weakness in some emerging market economies could turn out to be larger than envisaged, and notably a ""hard landing"" in China would be detrimental. Financial market volatility could increase given the uncertainty surrounding the normalisation of monetary policy in the US with potential consequences on asset prices and capital flows. Geopolitical tensions are keeping uncertainty at high levels and could become a larger impediment to investment spending than currently expected. Legacies from the crisis may continue to weigh more heavily on investment activity than expected, and fading tailwinds could not be replaced by more endogenous growth drivers.

But there are also upside risks, namely: Stronger or more persistent tailwinds would have a positive impact on economic growth. A stronger-than-expected revival in global growth dynamics and world trade could push demand for European exports more than expected. A more favourable impact from already-implemented and future structural reforms could also provide additional stimuli to economic growth.

[slide 12]: Budgetary outlook for 2016

The second important message coming out of these forecasts is the improving fiscal outlook, as the reduction in general government deficits continues: In the euro area, the deficit is forecast to stand at 2% of GDP in 2015 and to decline to 1.8% in 2016 and 1.5% in 2017. In the EU as a whole, the deficit is forecast at 2.5% of GDP in 2015 and to decline to 2% next year and 1.6% in 2017.

In most Member States, deficit ratios are projected to fall in 2015 and to continue on this path in 2016 and 2017. In the euro area, we expect only France, Spain and Greece to have deficits above the 3% of GDP threshold in 2016. The fiscal policy stance is expected to be broadly neutral in the euro area in 2015 and 2016, as the changes to the structural balance should be broadly nil in both years. The debt-to-GDP ratio is forecast to decline as of this year from the peak reached in 2014, and to reach 91.3% in the euro area and 85.8% in the EU in 2017. Our forecast takes into account revenue and expenditure trends and the inclusion of measures that were incorporated in the Draft Budgetary Plans for 2016, as submitted by euro-area Member States to the Commission by 15 October 2015. The forecast for 2017 rests on a no-policy-change assumption, since policy measures for that years have in most cases still to be specified by national authorities.

[slide 13]: Convergence in the euro area

Finally, and this would be my third message today, I would like to conclude with a few remarks on the issue of convergence in the euro area. In our Communication on steps towards completing the Economic and Monetary Union last month, we committed to work to facilitate convergence between euro area Member States. Looking at our Autumn Forecast, the picture so far is mixed.

First, potential growth paths are re-converging – but only very slowly. Some countries are catching up thanks to the implementation of structural reforms, but a timely implementation of these reforms is needed in order to improve the efficiency of labour- and product markets and further increase growth potential.

Second, labour-market conditions are improving – but disparities remain high. Unemployment is receding in most Member States but will still be 25.8% in Greece and 20.5% in Spain compared with 4.9% in Germany in 2016.

Third, the debt-to-GDP ratio has peaked in 2014 in the euro area as a whole – but in some Member States it is still expected to increase next year: among others, in Greece, France, Spain and Belgium. Finally, as regards the current account balance, former deficit countries have adjusted – while, overall, large savings and investment imbalances remain.As a result, the current-account surplus reaches a historically high level in the euro area. These positions are not expected to change significantly over the forecast horizon.

[Slide 14] Growth map 2016

To sum up, these are my key takeaways from this year's Autumn Forecast:

The European economy remains on recovery course.

Unemployment will continue to fall while remaining too high in many countries.

The recovery is still supported by well-known tailwinds, including low oil prices which are set to persist into 2016.

Other positive factors are increasingly taking over, such as the impact of structural reforms.

We project a soft landing for the Chinese economy and a rebound in other emerging economies' growth from 2016.

Inflation will gradually increase from its current very low level while remaining moderate.

Overall deficit and debt levels in the EU will decline.

Finally, further efforts are needed to support convergence in the euro area.

Today's forecast will provide the basis for a number of policy decisions to be taken over the next couple of weeks, notably the Commission’s Opinions on the euro area Member States’ Draft Budgetary Plans. The forecast will also feed into the preparation of the Annual Growth Survey and the Alert Mechanism Report on Macroeconomic Imbalances, which we will also be presenting later this month as we kick off the next European Semester of economic policy coordination.

If you would like to know about our policy conclusions deriving from today’s figures, I must therefore invite you to have a little more patience.

On our Autumn Forecast itself, I am happy to now take your questions.

column1: Responsabilité et solidarité: un an à la Commission européenne,28-10-2015,European Commission,European Commission,5760,"                                   European Commission - Speech - [Check Against Delivery]        Responsibility and solidarity: a year to the European Commission   Brussels, 28 October 2015            Speech by President Jean-Claude Juncker at the Plenary Session of the Economic, social and environmental (EESC) October 28, 2015 in ParisMr. President and dear friend, Excellency and dear friend, Madam President, Mr President of the European Economic and Social Committee, Distinguished Advisors, and for many of you to see the room, dear friends, I promised my friend John Paul I come to speak to you Due to the occasion of your plenary sessions. Exceptionally, I kept my word. But I understand that you have been kind enough to organize this session this morning to accommodate me, and I am grateful.I promised John Paul and my friend Olivier Kirsch, neighbor Lorraine Luxembourg and longtime partner. I told them that I attach great importance to this kind of meeting. I attach great importance to my meetings with representatives of civil society, labor representatives, employers, environmental, because it's here - and little else - that good political explanation must take place.Those who know me for a longer time will not be astonished that I attach great importance to the social dialogue at large. And national plans, and at European level, it was a constant in my political life over the past thirty years.My election as head of the Commission - in fact - did not make me change my mind. One, I'm too old to fundamentally change its mind - on the things of life. And two, I see - in Brussels and elsewhere - that social dialogue in the broad sense is down. We lost that ability to listen that has long characterized our way of living together, and I see that the gap between the political world, European public policy, and our people is widening.That's why I said when I took office that my Commission, the Commission would be the last chance. I'm not saying by the immodesty, but to emphasize the importance, yes, the urgency to see the European public action and sensibilities of our peoples closer together.As I wanted to show that I understood the message I wanted to make this Commission other than those which were our predecessors. I can not even make an assessment after a year - 1isNovember will be the first day of anniversary of the Commission I have the honor of chairing, we were elected by the European Parliament on 25 or 26 October, so exactly one year - I can not yet take stock, draw a review. We will draw up the balance sheet at autopsy, that is to say at the end of the mandate.I said at the beginning that the mandate of this Commission would be different from the Commission mandates that preceded us. It is true that it is a different Commission because the mode of election which took me to the Commission's head differs quite markedly from the way the Chairpersons of the Commission were appointed before. Previously, it was the Heads of State and Government who appointed the President of the Commission and the European Parliament had only to follow.This time the main European political families presented candidates list heads who campaigned throughout Europe, and therefore can be supported on a direct mandate from the people. Finally I know - I'm not absolutely certain that voters know it too. But they will know next time because when the next four years, we will repeat the exercise to appoint heads of lists and candidates for President of the Commission, our publics better understand what is being change in Europe.I began my tenure with the European Parliament, before Commissioners were not appointed, a policy statement by expanding to the European Parliament a list of ten policy priorities around which organize the work of the Commission.I said that the Commission is a political institution and not a combination of bureaucratic and technocratic criminals - why I have chosen as members of the Commission of the politicians who have a past and a future that: Alumni Prime Ministers, former foreign ministers, former ministers of finance, seasoned parliamentarians and others. So to give the Commission a political dimension it did not have before. We must be political and we will.Governments, Ministers - I know - do not always like this aspiration of the Commission. But finally, after a year, I must say they are beginning to accept the fact that the Commission is political and it is here to make a difference with what was around ten priorities that I have developed. And I hosted the Commission so that we can stop this elevator system that would each Commissioner handles in the corner of its own jurisdiction and not in interactivity with other commissioners. Why I named several vice presidents. The Vice-Presidents, by 1isNovember last year, held an honorary position. I asked them to hold an organizational function, inspiration and leadership to ensure that several commissioners groups to work better together. And I asked Commissioners and vice presidents to make policy oriented towards growth and employment, the high priority of this Commission.I'm a fan of what I always call the virtuous triangle: we must put our public finances, there is no alternative to this; we must continue to engage ambitious structural reforms since our economies must modernize; - And had to boost investment in Europe, investment oriented towards employment and growth - largely absent in recent years of European economic policies.So we presented, I must say in record time towards the end of November last year, an investment plan for Europe that bears my name. It is not me who invented this term are those who believe that this investment plan IS UNKNOWN no ​​success, thus anticipating, they wanted to name the responsible for this failure, so this investment plan door my name. 315 billion to boost investment in Europe - why? In Europe we have an unacceptable reduction of the investment effort. In 2013-2014, we had less investment than in 2007, the year before the crisis: 17% less investment. A major industrial country, the engine of economic growth in Europe, such as Germany lags behind in terms of investment between 1990 and 2013 by 52%. We are in investment failure and so you had at the European level, we followed up the investment to remedy this fault, really dangerous. And with the European Investment Bank, which is the Bank of the European Union, we launched the European Fund for Strategic Investment enriched bilateral national contributions including French. And this plan works surprisingly. There are investments that are taking shape in Europe, all over Europe, without which this plan would not have emerged because governments were unable to finance investment and the private sector was unable to assume the risks inherent in investment projects that carry far. And so I'm pretty happy starting this investment plan, notably in France and elsewhere, where beautiful projects that would not have made without the investment plan are taking shape.We launched since the investment is not without effort, the idea of ​​large digital European market. I was yesterday evening with the President of the Republic and the German Chancellor at the Elysee for an update on agreements and joint projects that are being done between Germany and France. And jointly developed projects are projects that have the mouth and are large. The digital single market is of paramount importance. Tomorrow's world will be first made by digital, the whole society is in the process of digitizing, with the risks that such a change of economic operational methods involved. But the road to more welfare, more growth and more competitiveness is paved with tablets and mobile phones, big data and cloud. The big data, the ""big datas"", as we say in French, already today represent a growth factor that should not be that we in -estimions. The big data sector is growing at a rate of 40% per year. The growth of big data sector is the sevenfold growth in the digital sector considered without big data. What we need to do is add a dose of Europe in this major undertaking that is the digital marketplace. We'll have to put a stop to these 28 national fragmentation that characterizes Europe since the digital single market does not exist. To compare Europe to China or the United States, we are ridiculous. Investors fail to bring decision makers to make the right decisions because there are too many regulators, there are too divergent national rules. This will require that we put ourselves at the service of progress that will quickly since digital markets go towards more unity while Europe remains in a fragmented world, what prevents us from doing what we should do.Similarly, we launched the EU capital markets, which is a way to improve the financing of our economies are too dependent on the banking sector alone and we must do everything to enable especially small and medium enterprises - which are a huge growth area if we support economic actors - to have a more accurate, easier, more sustainable capital markets. I do not invite us to imitate the US, but the US, the use of capital markets is stronger, more developed than it is in Europe. The European economy is too dependent on the banking sector alone, which is an imbalance, which we will have portions remedy.As we launched the modernization program oriented towards jobs and growth, we launched a real European Union energy to increase in intensity and number energy interconnections between the different European countries. This is an important ambition, Europe imports 53% of its energy supply from other parts of the world including Russia. We'll have to put a stop to this dangerous energy dependence that accuses Europe with regard to Russia. I'm not someone who can not say bad about Russia, I think it will also better that we learn to live in Europe with Russia, since Russia remains a strategically important partner and there is no security, no lasting peace in Europe without a good understanding among the countries of the European Union and Russia. But the fact remains that we are too dependent on Russia in terms of energy imports. Europe imports for 400 billion per year energy that comes from the outside. There is better use to make these 400 billion fund that the exporting countries.This is an important point in relation to the summit to be held in Paris in December, where Europe must play its role and to ensure that this commitment was ours - to achieve at least 40% off emissions by 2030 from the level of '90 - must be held to set an example for others to lead others, to ensure that tomorrow's world will be a place where young people can still live tomorrow at least in such good conditions that today's generations. And therefore will require us to do so - the Commission is doing it - to conclude in Paris a global climate deal that is ambitious, that is strong, that is sustainable and which is especially compelling. Good intentions do not produce good policy, and it is necessary that the system we will implement will be a binding system and your Council will have a full role to play in particular accompanying the French authorities on this path which will lead, I hope an ambitious agreement in December.Union Energy, Union Capital, Investment plan: all these projects will remain insufficient if we fail to draw the financial and economic crisis of recent years the right lessons. So, it will follow that the Member States, not literally, but in general, the proposals that the Commission will do and has done in terms of deepening the economic and monetary union. We must strengthen our common rules. We have already done, and we started to build a banking union that allows us to empower banks and limit the consequences of irresponsible behavior for public finances, for savers and taxpayers. And therefore will require that we improve the economic governance of the euro area remains weak because underdeveloped. Just as it is to ensure that the principles of seriousness, rigor or austerity where necessary, continue to apply the principles of solidarity must remain so also.I resented the so-called Greek crisis was because too many governments that wanted to exclude, keep Greece in the eurozone. If we had yielded to this ahistorical requirement, we would have given the starting signal for the decomposition of the economic zone and the European currency area. It was therefore in the interest of Greece and the euro area to ensure that Greece can remain a member of the eurozone, may the stay in a sustainable manner, while allowing it to restore its economy to an equally sustainable. I have ensured that the efforts - because efforts are many - the Greeks are distributed in a more equitable manner this time than the previous times, and you saw that for the first time the Commission has established a study on the social impact of adjustment measures that have been taken in Greece.I always, even as the President of the Eurogroup, as I was for eight years, regretted that we discuss when we all ficelions adjustment programs, but we have little attention for social consequences of the decisions we have taken together with the governments concerned. Now if structural adjustment of public finances and economies means social deconstruction, these plans never bear fruit, so that it will henceforth we be more attentive to the social consequences of our collective actions.We recently published the report of the five Presidents, since I had chosen to associate the President of the European Parliament in this effort. The plan of the five Presidents constitutes a roadmap that will occupy us over the coming years. In the implementation of this Plan there are things I know they hinder governments - well, I'm not here to embarrass governments, and governments also should understand that they are not there to obstruct the Commission - but it must brainstorm wearing away. It will take that in Europe we dotions a deposit guarantee system that is European, with modalities to be developed, but the general idea is that we need a European deposit guarantee system. Then, it will take us to organize in a more intelligent way, that is to say different, the external representation of the euro area. We are absolutely ridiculous. I, as President of the Eurogroup, I attended the meetings of the International Monetary Fund, the meetings of the G7, the G20 meetings, and there were too many Europeans around the table. Should the euro zone, which is an admittedly imperfect area, but consistent, be represented by a single European representative at the table of the major international institutions. Ballet chairs, where we brought the President of the Central Bank, then told him to leave for a while because it takes the Eurogroup President occupies the chair, see the French, Italian and German speak sometimes in opposite arguing their point of view, does not allow us to give to those who observe us from afar the idea that Europe is a well-organized system. This will require that we réorganisions the external representation of the area.That is why, moreover, we have revised the rules that control the sequence of steps that are part of the European semester, when it comes to better coordinate our economic policies. Again, it would with more enthusiasm governments follow the recommendations that the Commission makes under the European semester, a semester of coordination of our national policies so they do not develop in a way contradictory. We have chosen to reduce the number of recommendations. So far the Commission and the Council adopted the emitted and at the location of each member state 10, 15, 20 national recommendations. Result: they were not implemented. Governments that had adopted them themselves did not care passionately. Too many recommendations kill recommendations. And this time we have chosen to emit less country-specific recommendations and I would like the governments of the republics and monarchies of the few that remain following, in their wisdom, the original wisdom of the Commission when it issued recommendations national.In this context, Mr. President, let me say a word about the transatlantic economic relationship. I know the United States well, less than France, but all the same, and I see in my discussions with President Obama and other US officials that everything slowly, without saying it, without notify us the US is trying to divert their attention from Europe to cast their gaze - bringing far - on the peaceful world.You saw that, without very great problems, a commercial treaty was concluded with the countries of Asia Pacific in particular. And now we are negotiating a treaty between the United States and Europe that - it's the least we can say - no direct access to the heart of Europeans since many Europeans believe we're selling out, sell the virtues and European principles. That will not happen. There is no question of reducing down our levels of environmental protection, levels of social protection, our standard in cultural matters. Europe is not for sale, Europe is not to buy. So we stick to the principles that have made and are still, I think, the strength of Europe. But it will be that if we can not bring in a system of balanced and symmetrical combination, the views of Americans and ours, we will be the losers in the construction of the commercial world of tomorrow. If tomorrow, we want rules, the standards are set by the United States and our Asian friends, let us refrain. But if we want to keep an influence on the major issues that are the subject of which will be made tomorrow's world, we must act. We must act on a good foundation, I have recalled, but we must put ourselves in a position to be perceived as a credible interlocutor in the world, not only in the world across the Atlantic, but in the world as a whole .Speaking of this transatlantic treaty, I mean a word - as your President has wished - the social dimension of Europe is inadequately furnished. I say always. The social dimension is largely absent from European integration. This also explains the désadhésion the popular classes and the world of workers in relation to Europe. It's dangerous, this disenchantment of those who were in their heart, and that required at every moment, the European construction. The world of work is not the accomplice of European integration as it is made today. Will require that we make very serious changes in our thinking social Europe. It's still not an obscene word to say that Europe must also be supported by a social ambition. We have economic ambitions, we have ambitions left and right, but we are very weak when it comes to describing our social ambitions - why the Commission during the first half of 2016, will offer to the meditation of governments and national parliaments, and therefore committees and boards of the type of yours, a foundation of minimum social rights that will be developed in a way that the idea that Europe must also be social and have minimum standards or better perceived by governments, parliaments, by the boards like yours and by the general public.The European Union is not in a good condition, look outs, the Solidarity cracks, relevant discounts, doubts, hesitations that accompany the process of European unification. This is especially visible in relation to the migration issue and I would like to congratulate Oliver and the Council in general, to have been able to adopt last night, I believe, unanimously the report on migration, obviously I have not read, allowing me to speak with great authority; because I understand that in general, in terms of analysis and action, what you offer unanimously - which is rare and what honors you as this has required considerable efforts each other - and that the Commission proposes are almost identical.I had already said, taking my position that migration policies would be among the ten major priority for the Commission. At the time, in July, September last year, few people took seriously this requirement; but who knows the world knew that the migration would reach us much, soon. There are 2.3% of the world population is moving; more than 230 million men and women, so it was only a matter of time before we see land in many unfortunate people who do not have the chance to live like our sun but, since that they were born, to live in the shadows. With the war in Syria, unrest in North Africa, the breakdown of the Libyan state, the time was near, already last year, when Europe would face one of its biggest challenges since 30 , 40 years. I mean here, as I have said elsewhere, that those who come here deserve respect. Those who leave do not pleasure. Those who leave, as a rule, are not the laziest. Those who leave for better living and to enable their families and their children to live better, in general, are worn by very impressive packets of energy, talent and expertise. And so it is our duty to integrate those who come in our societies. This is the idea of ​​man that I am and that is a certain idea of ​​Europe that I would not want us to let destroy by populist forces of the extreme right and populist forces, and the forces who do not like each other. If we do not like each other that comes from elsewhere, it will stop one day to love us. There is not the world and Europe on the one hand, there is Europe in the world. And it will show that we know that Europe is not an invention itself will require us to be less self-centered, but will require that we put our ambitions and talents to the entire planet.Why I convened last Sunday of a Western Balkans Summit, where the migration pressure is more noticeable than in other countries together with Austria and Germany, which are somewhat in the same boat. And it is curious that the President of the European Commission should convene a meeting in Brussels with the countries of the Western Balkans - together with Serbia, FYROM and Albania - that these countries talk to each other. It is still amazing in Europe - in the European Union - d'avoir seven Member States who do not speak, who have the same problem and who do not have the energy to try to solve this problem if speaking. Migrants come from one country to another, and the country from where they come is not even informs the country to where they go, and the country where they came from is not able to 'informer the country the next step there are people on the streets. Sometimes I have the impression that viewers know more about the movements of migrants that the rulers. And so you had to put together all these governments so they can talk and say the four truths. If you do not tell your neighbor why you do not, you will never love him. So we insisted on a show and d'invectives of attacks which I had not thought they could take place in Europe. This is due to the fact that governments and societies do not talk. We have now found a solution that will be solved if it is applied. Until now we have devoted much time to the issue of refugees, but the decisions we took were never followed Effects. On September 23, we decided to put 3.5 billion euros more to be funded from national budgets in the service of political refugees. 400 million have reached us during the last weeks - 2.3 billion still missing. Frontex has requested 775 additional agents; promised, swore, 300 are on site. If we continue like this - not only we will not solve problems, but we will be ridiculous. Those watching from afar, Jordanians, Lebanese, Turks - when I talk to them they say: what is actually your problem, you have 0.11% of refugees in the territory of the European Union. Lebanon more than half the population, even Jordan, Turkey hosts its territory 2.5 million refugees and we say, come on, do what you can do for the refugees remain at home. But then you have to pay the price. Europe should pay the price: welcome refugees who deserve it, that is to say of asylum seekers; will require that we make a clear distinction between those who have a right to asylum and the so-called economic refugees, who have good reason to leave, but do not have very good reasons to stay. I want those to whom we grant the right to asylum can leave home when calm - I dream - will be back on the banks of the other side of the Mediterranean, but I would not want us to put the right undermined 'asile and the Geneva Conventions. The right to asylum is a right - it is not discussed, it is a requirement, it is a burning obligation of Europe experts should the right to asylum to those persecuted for political reasons, religious or others.And then you have to pay the price. He will have to find an agreement with Turkey on a joint action program for refugees. We are currently negotiating. Negotiations are nearing completion. I would like to say that, of course I understand the doubts and hesitations of those who say we can not reach an agreement with Erdoğan. But who else in Turkey? If Turkey, to put it simply, opens the valves there will be 2 to 3 million refugees who come in addition to the number of refugees that we have already shelter and then there will be a movement in Jordan, Lebanon to Turkey. So Turkey is not going to ensure that refugees can remain on Turkish territory. So it will take us to pay the price to the Turks. And I know it's an idea that is not very popular because human rights, freedom of the press, so I often speak with Erdoğan, but we have a problem that we must solve together and agreement with Turkey and we will.On refugees will require us to change the Dublin system, it no longer works. If it does not work, we can not apply it. And therefore the Commission will make relevant proposals in the spring of 2016 if possible.I wish we dotions Europe of a legal migration system. I say no to illegal immigration, but I say a big yes to legal migration. Europe saw its demographic state needs legal migration. In the early 20th century, 20% of the world population was European, now 7% of the world population is European, and by the end of the century, 4% of the world population of 10 billion will be European. So we need migration, but migration of organized, structured migration, legal migration and therefore the Commission will do over the coming months, the proposals in this direction.I would like, ladies and gentlemen Councillors, that Europe is a continent on the move, not a continent only to look at himself, but a continent can be proud of what he could achieve in the 50, 60 years. We are sufficiently proud of Europe. We did all the same great things together. We are often awful but on the essential: to ensure that peace reigns in Europe, this continent so often martyred; ensure we bring a single currency - but surprisingly difficult business successful business when you consider that until now we have merged in a single currency 19 national currencies - imagine yourself Europe and its status after the war of Iraq, after the economic and financial crisis without the euro, we would have had 15, 19 governments from all over the place, we would have 15.19 national central banks of conflicting policies, contradictory; not Europe goes better with great achievements, including the domestic market, we have managed to accumulate over the past years.We must continue. We must continue to remain proud of Europe. And it will ensure that future generations, they, can be proud of what we've done as we can be proud of the performance of previous generations. My father was a soldier during World War II, was forbidden my mother to go to school because the Germans had banned French is taught in Luxembourg schools, since Luxembourg is trilingual. We must speak the languages ​​of our neighbors because the French and the Germans stubbornly refuse to learn Luxembourgish. So we chose to study their languages. I also say because another dimension, so it does not fall within the area of ​​Community competence remains, as I said, inadequately furnished and is is the cultural dimension. Europe is also its cultural heritage, more reason not to give certain requirements that come from the other side of the Atlantic.Europe needs to make further progress in working order, civil society, trade unions, employers, farmers and the agricultural world I would never say enough how Europe is dependent on the daily performance of those working and till the land. Europe needs of your Board is good advice.Europe, itself, needs to move forward, yes determination and patience, the determination and patience needed by high ambitions and long distances. Thank you for your attention.
