Do we need to be reminded that the principle of mutual acceptance is what
binds Europe together as a whole?
Ladies and Gentlemen,
Europe has the political and cultural resources it needs to allow immigrants
to be successfully integrated into society. So, let us make the most of them
here and now. We hold the future in our hands.
Thank you.

Joaquín Almunia European Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Policy Achievements and Challenges of the Economic and Monetary Union Barcelona Graduate School of Economics – Inaugural Lecture Barcelona, 15 October 2007,15-10-2007,European Commission,European Commission,2666,"           SPEECH/07/627 Joaquín Almunia European Commissioner for Economic and Monetary PolicyAchievements and Challenges of the Economic and Monetary Union Barcelona Graduate School of Economics – Inaugural LectureBarcelona, 15 October 2007 Honourable President of the Generalitat, Ms. Minister, Magnificences, Presidente de la Barcelona Graduate School of Economics, Authorities, Ladies and Gentlemen,  friends Thank you for inviting me today to this inauguration. Usually this kind of ritual begin by expressing the honor and satisfaction that represents address an audience as distinguished in an occasion like this.  Believe me when I say that, in my case, my initial words of thanks not feel at all hollow, not even formal. In all honesty, when Andreu Mas-Collel proposed me to join this project I was really excited and since then I follow closely and consider it as their own. Power today pronounce the inaugural lecture of the School it is not at all a procedural obligation but a pleasure. The Barcelona GSE has already become an academic project at the highest level, with a Scientific Committee and world-renowned faculty and enviable location as the city of Barcelona, ​​which certainly adds value and prestige to the school. In a moment I will speak of the Economic and Monetary Union, which is not only the first economic and trade area in the world, but also the basis of a pioneering political project.  As European Commissioner responsible for ensuring their proper functioning I can attest to the growing complexity of economic and financial processes of an increasingly globalized and interdependent world.  This complexity poses increasingly difficult challenges to policymakers, monetary authorities, participants in financial markets and business leaders. From that perspective, I can only congratulate the launch of a school that will help train economists of the highest level with clear international vocation, which will enhance our collective ability to understand and try to guide these complex processes. I wish it the greatest success. I am convinced that, under the chairmanship of Professor Andreu Mas-Colell, the Barcelona Graduate School of Economics soon occupy a prominent place among the international economy schools place. Let me now to continue in English to deliver this inaugural lecture. In May 2nd 1998, the Ecofin Council decided to go ahead with the 3rd stage of the EMU, considering that eleven member states fulfilled the requirements to participate in the euro. The 1st of January 1999 the single currency became a reality. The 10th anniversary of this decision offers a very good occasion to take stock of our experiences since the beginning of such an ambitious initiative, and to draw lessons that will orient future economic policy in the euro area.  Therefore, a few months before this anniversary I would like to share with you some reflections about the history, the functioning and the challenges of EMU, probably the most important step forward of Europe since the Treaty of Rome.  I will begin with a brief retrospective reviewing the hopes, expectations and ideas that shaped the construction of EMU before assessing whether those expectations have been born out in the first 10 years of the euro's existence. Finally, I will try to draw some lessons for the future.  The theory behind EMU The idea of creating a monetary union between the economies of the European Union had been explored as early as the 1960s. However, it was the oil price shocks of the 70s and 80s, followed by the crisis in the Economic and Monetary System which reinforced the political commitment to launch the third stage of EMU. Indeed, the euro's launch in 1999 was also a logical next step following the creation of the Single Market.  The benefits of a European single currency area were deemed to outweigh the risks. By reducing transaction costs and risk premiums, it was hoped that the euro would boost trade and finance between EMU countries. And as exchange rate risks and currency costs vanished, a better use of resources could be achieved, not least because greater transparency would foster competition. It was also hoped that by fostering integration and peer pressure, the likelihood of gross mistakes in economic policy would diminish.  With the benefit of hindsight, we can consider that some upbeat expectations regarding the consequences of EMU took into consideration the positive impact of the nominal convergence achieved during the previous years and the cyclical upswing. However, there was no doubt back then that the creation of the world's largest monetary union would pose challenges. The prospect of adopting a single currency while retaining national decentralised fiscal policy, plus the social, cultural and regulatory diversity across the Member States, fuelled doubts regarding the feasibility of the project.  Moreover, during the three decades of analysis and debate that led up to monetary union, a core question centred on how the internal dynamics of EMU would respond in the face of external or country specific shocks.  Everybody knew that some of the conditions for the good functioning of the optimum currency areas were not met at that time, in particular in the domain of labour mobility and labour market flexibility. Quite a number of anglo-saxon economists and observers anticipated that the single currency will never exist, or that the euro will fail in a short period of time.      Fortunately, they were wrong. Appraising a decade of EMU Today, with the single currency approaching its tenth year, and the euro area economy having gone through one full business cycle, we can begin assessing the performance of EMU and gage how its functioning has measured up to expectations.  However, this is not a straightforward task. It goes without saying that developments in the euro area economy since 1999 are not solely the result of Economic and Monetary Union.  The economic impact of EMU must be disentangled from other factors that have affected economic performance, such as the initial start up shocks experienced in several Member States, the different levels of convergence in countries across the euro area as well as the influence of global factors on trade and financial flows. These considerations notwithstanding, there is still ample evidence that EMU has made a promising start. For example, those who argued the stability benefits of a European monetary union are today vindicated.     Indeed, EMU has developed a stable macroeconomic framework that has helped the euro area economy weather a series of external shocks – including the impact of 9/11, the recent rise in oil prices as well as the current financial turmoil. EMU has removed the risks stemming from intra euro area exchange rate volatility and has de facto made exchange rate developments much less relevant for our economies than one or two decades ago. As a consequence of greater macroeconomic stability, inflation has declined to around 2% and has been matched by a sharp fall in nominal and real interest rates.  On top of that, employment growth during this decade has led to around 15 million new jobs in the euro area, 3.5 million of them in 2006, and the unemployment rate is the lowest of the last 15 years. EMU's role as a catalyst for trade and investment has also largely met expectations. Although figures vary, a conservative estimate puts the euro's boost to internal trade as somewhere in the region of 5-15%. Meanwhile, recent estimates of EMU's impact of inward foreign direct investment cite figures as high as 60%. The euro's positive impact can also been seen in today's highly integrated financial markets, particularly in the markets for derivatives and corporate bonds.  The euro has rapidly become a leading international currency. In a relatively short space of time, the euro established its role in foreign exchange and international security markets and has become an important reserve currency, a reflection of the confidence and credibility it has built up over a decade. Regardless the present concerns vis-à-vis the evolution of the euro exchange rate, the fact that the single currency is becoming more and more trustful and reliable has indeed very important political consequences for the external role of the EU in the global world. Of course, there is no denying that as a flipside to these achievements, EMU has faced a number of challenges. A key challenge has undoubtedly been the euro area's sluggish productivity. As a result, growth has averaged just over 2% a year, a figure that compares unfavourably with the US which grew at roughly 3% over the same period.  Certainly the euro area's recovery from the slowdown of 2001-2002 was not as rapid as expected. We can trace this poor performance partly to pro-cyclical fiscal policies employed in the buoyant period of 1999-2001. But perhaps more significantly, insufficient product, labour and capital market reforms have failed to boost productivity in many countries. It is not a secret that the first five years of implementation of the Lisbon agenda did not lived up to our expectations. And the first years of EMU have not only been characterised by modest growth rates overall, but also a varying economic performance across euro area countries. If we take the period 2002 – 2006, the average annual growth in Spain, Luxembourg and Finland was above 3%, but below 1% in Portugal, Italy and Germany.  This observation, together with a similar divergence in inflation levels and in the evolution of unit labour costs across the euro area, brings me to the second key challenge experienced by EMU; that is the difficulty of securing efficient adjustment to shocks and country specific developments between euro area economies.   In the absence of a national monetary policy, adjustment to external shocks or country specific developments should take place through the competitiveness channel. This is where costs and prices respond to a rise or fall in the level of demand in an economy, adapting its competitiveness and converging economic activity with the euro area average.  However, for this channel to work efficiently, it needs an environment where prices can adjust freely in integrated and flexible markets. For the most part, it is those countries that have not made progress towards economic flexibility through structural reforms that have experienced adjustment and competitiveness problems under the euro. Policy developments and lessons To a degree, the challenges and achievements I have just described show how much the policy choices and political context have shaped the development of EMU over the last decade.  The institutional setting of EMU has also had a crucial impact on its functioning. This setting is based on a set of rules – such as the 3% and 60% reference values for deficit and debt - that were defined in the Maastricht Treaty and later confirmed by the Stability and Growth Pact.   This framework reflected the political context and dominant ideas of the time, which placed a premium on ensuring macroeconomic stability and fiscal discipline.  But the political commitment in order to fulfil the convergence criteria was not based in a strong consensus regarding the adequate policies for the next period, once the euro was launched. And the leaders of the biggest euro area countries didn't realise fully the conditions under which EMU should work efficiently.  Only a few years after its inception, the Stability and Growth Pact had begun to run into difficulties. The crisis of 2003, when France and Germany failed to respect the rules of the Pact, coincided with the growing realisation that the Lisbon Strategy was failing to deliver.  The bad economic results obtained and the need to overcome the slowdown created appropriate conditions to discuss how to improve the overall institutional setting, one that would take a more comprehensive approach to economic policies in EMU. As part of this new approach, both the Pact and the Lisbon Strategy were revised in 2005.  The new Stability and Growth Pact put more emphasis on preventive, rather than corrective measures, on achieving fiscal sustainability over the medium and long term and included incentives for member States to embark on structural reforms.  The revised Lisbon Strategy refocused priorities on growth and employment, put more emphasis on national ownership and assigned major responsibilities to fiscal policy. In this way, a strong link was established between the implantation of structural reforms and sound fiscal policies.  Today, consensus has increased and the renewed institutional setting is working better. Fiscal discipline is reducing deficits and debts and, though progress may still be slow in some countries, finance ministers have recognised the need to reach their medium term budgetary objectives, especially in view of the challenges to public finances posed by ageing.  On the other hand, the urgent need for structural reform in certain member states is being fully understood. There is a wider recognition of the extent to which lack of reform in one country can influence the euro area economy as a whole. Indeed, given the interdependence of economies in EMU and the role played by spill-overs, it is essential that we summon a coordinated effort to deepen structural reforms efforts in the euro area.  Structural reforms are vital to tackle the challenges faced by EMU, as they both raise potential growth and smooth adjustment. Particular attention is required in the services sector, which accounts for 60% of the EU's wealth and where market opening has been painfully slow. Measures to increase competition in this sector could boost productivity as well as foster price flexibility.  In the labour market, ensuring that wages are linked more strongly to productivity would help prevent divergences in competitiveness, while more integrated financial markets could help smooth adjustment to country-specific developments through cross-border risk sharing. Of course, in the current climate of financial turmoil, any further integration of financial services must be accompanied by greater attention to stability and supervisory arrangements.  Although the importance of structural reform for the smooth functioning of EMU has come to the fore, it is essential that appropriate fiscal policies continue to prevail in the euro area. Population ageing will have a severe impact on the public finances of euro area countries as pressures on pension and healthcare spending rise. Rapidly reducing fiscal deficits and debts now is extremely important to safeguard public finance sustainability in the long term.  It is of utmost importance that euro area members move rapidly towards their medium term objectives – in other words, the specific target agreed by each Member State for achieving a budget balanced in structural terms, and not just to safeguard sustainability. Securing a sound budgetary position ensures that the economy will stabilise around a higher and stable growth trend over the cycle. It also smoothes adjustment by allowing automatic stabilisers to work fully in the event of an economic slowdown without triggering excessive budget deficits.   Meeting these and other challenges requires an effective system of economic governance for the euro area. The Eurogroup, where euro area finance ministers meet every month, is already beginning to develop a common understanding on a number of policy issues, including fiscal policy, and awareness is growing of the specific economic challenges that face the euro area.  However, we now need to channel this awareness and understanding into a more coordinated and concrete approach to policy making in EMU.  This is the real challenge for a good governance of the euro area, instead of discussing again and again the independence of the ECB. The considerations, questions and challenges that I have raised today will form part of a broader evaluation of the functioning of Economic and Monetary Union taking place in the months ahead. Next May, when you will be concluding your academic year in the Barcelona GSE, as we celebrate EMU's 10th Anniversary, I will present the results of this analysis and propose a new set of guidelines for the euro area policies that will steer a stronger EMU in the 21st century. I wish to both of them plenty of success.  Just now. President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, friends This is a very good initiative. For Barcelona, ​​in Catalonia, in Spain and in Europe. Congratulations and much success! Barcelona Graduate School of Economics – Inaugural

Lecture

Barcelona, 15 October 2007
Molt Honorable President de la Generalitat,
Sra. Ministra,
Rectores Magnificos,
Presidente de la Barcelona Graduate School of Economics,
Autoridades,
Senyores, Senyors,
Amics,
Moltes gracies per haver-me convidat avui a aquesta inauguració.
Suele ser ritual comenzar este tipo de intervención expresando el honor
y la satisfacción que representa dirigirse a una audiencia tan distinguida
en una ocasión como ésta.
Créanme si les digo que, en mi caso, mis palabras iniciales de
agradecimiento no las siento en absoluto huecas, ni tan siquiera formales. Con
toda sinceridad, cuando Andreu Mas-Collel me propuso asociarme a este proyecto
me hizo mucha ilusión y desde entonces lo sigo de cerca y lo considero como
algo propio.
Poder hoy pronunciar la lección inaugural de la Escuela no es en
absoluto una obligación de trámite, sino un gran placer.
La Barcelona GSE se ha convertido ya en un proyecto académico del
más alto nivel, con un Comité científico y un equipo docente de
renombre mundial y una localización tan envidiable como la ciudad de
Barcelona, que sin duda añade valor y prestigio a la Escuela.
Dentro de unos instantes voy a hablarles de la Unión Económica y
Monetaria, que no sólo es el primer espacio económico y comercial del
mundo, sino también la base de un proyecto político pionero.
Como Comisario europeo encargado de velar por su buen funcionamiento puedo
dar fe de la complejidad creciente de los procesos económicos y financieros
de un mundo cada vez más globalizado e interdependiente.
Una complejidad que plantea retos cada vez más difíciles a los
responsables políticos, a las autoridades monetarias, a los participantes
en los mercados financieros y a los líderes empresariales.
Desde esa perspectiva, no puedo más que felicitarme por la puesta en
marcha de una escuela que contribuirá a formar economistas de
primerísimo nivel con vocación claramente internacional, lo que
reforzará nuestra capacidad colectiva de entender e intentar orientar esos
procesos complejos.
Os deseo pues el mayor de los éxitos. Estoy convencido de que, bajo la
presidencia del profesor Andreu Mas-Colell, la Barcelona Graduate School of
Economics ocupará muy pronto un lugar destacado entre las escuelas de
economía internacionales.

prices can adjust freely in integrated and flexible markets. For the most part,
it is those countries that have not made progress towards economic flexibility
through structural reforms that have experienced adjustment and competitiveness
problems under the euro.
Policy developments and lessons
To a degree, the challenges and achievements I have just described show how
much the policy choices and political context have shaped the development of EMU
over the last decade.
The institutional setting of EMU has also had a crucial impact on its
functioning. This setting is based on a set of rules – such as the 3% and
60% reference values for deficit and debt - that were defined in the Maastricht
Treaty and later confirmed by the Stability and Growth Pact.
This framework reflected the political context and dominant ideas of the
time, which placed a premium on ensuring macroeconomic stability and fiscal
discipline.
But the political commitment in order to fulfil the convergence criteria was
not based in a strong consensus regarding the adequate policies for the next
period, once the euro was launched. And the leaders of the biggest euro area
countries didn't realise fully the conditions under which EMU should work
efficiently.
Only a few years after its inception, the Stability and Growth Pact had begun
to run into difficulties. The crisis of 2003, when France and Germany failed to
respect the rules of the Pact, coincided with the growing realisation that the
Lisbon Strategy was failing to deliver.
The bad economic results obtained and the need to overcome the slowdown
created appropriate conditions to discuss how to improve the overall
institutional setting, one that would take a more comprehensive approach to
economic policies in EMU. As part of this new approach, both the Pact and the
Lisbon Strategy were revised in 2005.
The new Stability and Growth Pact put more emphasis on preventive, rather
than corrective measures, on achieving fiscal sustainability over the medium and
long term and included incentives for member States to embark on structural
reforms.
The revised Lisbon Strategy refocused priorities on growth and employment,
put more emphasis on national ownership and assigned major responsibilities to
fiscal policy. In this way, a strong link was established between the
implantation of structural reforms and sound fiscal policies.
Today, consensus has increased and the renewed institutional setting is
working better. Fiscal discipline is reducing deficits and debts and, though
progress may still be slow in some countries, finance ministers have recognised
the need to reach their medium term budgetary objectives, especially in view of
the challenges to public finances posed by ageing.
On the other hand, the urgent need for structural reform in certain member
states is being fully understood. There is a wider recognition of the extent to
which lack of reform in one country can influence the euro area economy as a
whole. Indeed, given the interdependence of economies in EMU and the role played
by spill-overs, it is essential that we summon a coordinated effort to deepen
structural reforms efforts in the euro area.
Structural reforms are vital to tackle the challenges faced by EMU, as they
both raise potential growth and smooth adjustment. Particular attention is
required in the services sector, which accounts for 60% of the EU's wealth and
where market opening has been painfully slow. Measures to increase competition
in this sector could boost productivity as well as foster price flexibility.
In the labour market, ensuring that wages are linked more strongly to
productivity would help prevent divergences in competitiveness, while more
integrated financial markets could help smooth adjustment to country-specific
developments through cross-border risk sharing. Of course, in the current
climate of financial turmoil, any further integration of financial services must
be accompanied by greater attention to stability and supervisory arrangements.
Although the importance of structural reform for the smooth functioning of
EMU has come to the fore, it is essential that appropriate fiscal policies
continue to prevail in the euro area. Population ageing will have a severe
impact on the public finances of euro area countries as pressures on pension and
healthcare spending rise. Rapidly reducing fiscal deficits and debts now is
extremely important to safeguard public finance sustainability in the long term.
It is of utmost importance that euro area members move rapidly towards their
medium term objectives – in other words, the specific target agreed by
each Member State for achieving a budget balanced in structural terms, and not
just to safeguard sustainability. Securing a sound budgetary position ensures
that the economy will stabilise around a higher and stable growth trend over the
cycle. It also smoothes adjustment by allowing automatic stabilisers to work
fully in the event of an economic slowdown without triggering excessive budget
deficits.
Meeting these and other challenges requires an effective system of economic
governance for the euro area. The Eurogroup, where euro area finance ministers
meet every month, is already beginning to develop a common understanding on a
number of policy issues, including fiscal policy, and awareness is growing of
the specific economic challenges that face the euro area.
However, we now need to channel this awareness and understanding into a more
coordinated and concrete approach to policy making in EMU.  This is the real
challenge for a good governance of the euro area, instead of discussing again
and again the independence of the ECB.
The considerations, questions and challenges that I have raised today will
form part of a broader evaluation of the functioning of Economic and Monetary
Union taking place in the months ahead. Next May, when you will be concluding
your academic year in the Barcelona GSE, as we celebrate EMU's 10th Anniversary,
I will present the results of this analysis and propose a new set of guidelines
for the euro area policies that will steer a stronger EMU in the 21st
century.
I wish to both of them plenty of success.

Benita Ferrero-Waldner Membre de la Commission européenne chargée des relations extérieures et de la politique européenne de voisinage Representing the Union abroad: Key challenges for the years ahead Réunion des chefs de délégation de la Commission européenne Bruxelles, le 10 septembre 2007,11-09-2007,European Commission,European Commission,3280,"           SPEECH/07/514 Benita Ferrero-Waldner Member of the European Commissioner for External Relations and European Neighbourhood PolicyRepresenting the Union abroad: Key challenges for the years ahead Meeting of the Heads of Delegation of the European CommissionBrussels, 10 September 2007 Ladies and gentlemen, colleagues,  I am happy to see you all gathered here two years after our last meeting.  Over the past three years, I had the opportunity to meet with many of you and to realize the excellent work you do every day. Many of youwork in very difficult situationsI think in particular of Ilkka Uusitalo and his team, who face the constant threat of bombings in Baghdad and Jan de Cook, Which experienced several days of curfew in Islamabad in July, to mention only two of you. But there are many other circumstances in which each of you can face difficult situations, if not dangerous.   I would also like to take a moment to pay tribute to our colleagues who lost their lives during the past year. I think, in particular,Alessandro Missir of Lusignan, Our delegation in Morocco, and, last month, to Jean-Pierre Pierard our delegation in New Caledonia and Michel Gauché Fiji.   * * * Dear colleagues, We have now passed half of the mandate of the current Commission. Also, I would like that together, we come back to some of our key achievements of the last three years, before interest us the strategic challenges we face and how we respond to an institutional perspective and operational. Next month, the Portuguese Presidency hopes to finalize a Reform Treaty which will introduce significant changes in our jurisdiction. So it was with particular interest that we will hear this afternoon the President, who is invited for the first time, on my initiative, to attend our meeting and will be represented by Secretary of State for European Affairs Lobo Antunes this afternoon. (1 Achievements) I would first like to remind some of our accomplishments. We faced a number ofextremely demanding and unpredictable challenges; from natural disasters such as the December 2004 tsunami and the recent earthquake in Peru, to political crises. I refer specifically to the need to establish aTIM, the ""TIM""to deliver our aid to the Palestinian Territories. I also think the management of theLebanese crisisin July last year. The release of the detained medical personnelLibyawas also a great success for the EU and in fact for the Commission. In this regard, I would also take this opportunity to express my gratitude toMarc Pierini.  These various challenges have all been managed exceptionallyThis has enhanced the growing reputation of the Commission in terms of the effectiveness of its response in crisis situations. We must, indeed, be able to react quickly under extreme temporal and political constraints. Butwe must also defend our strategic interests. That is why we also continued to strengthen our strategic relationships with key players in the international scene.ResultingIn particular, a renewed strategy regarding the ChinaIn which we proposed to develop a closer partnership but also to assume more responsibility.  As to United States, Former clouds that have darkened our relationship have largely dissipated and we continue to build the indispensable partnership between us and the country. This partnership will be further strengthened by the new Transatlantic Economic Council we launched this year to reduce the regulatory burden. We are working in parallel on political and security issues that concern the main crisis areas around the world, and I think we are, increasingly, truly perceived by Washington as an actor that counts. We talk constantly with our neighborRussiaon the most diverse topics. The partnership must be developed, and we do our best to achieve it, but we also need the support of Moscow. The Vienna summit in May 2006 led to an ambitious work program with theLatin America and the first summit between the EU and Brazilconfirmed the status of ""strategic partner"" of the country. It's the same with theSouth Africa, Who also joined the exclusive club of ""strategic partners"". We have strengthened the political pillar of our partnership with theJapan. Country Last but not least, thein: We are now implementing the ambitious action plan adopted two years ago. Along with these strategic partnerships, we entered into a new partnership with theCentral Asia and we have opened negotiations for new Partnership and Cooperation Agreements with the China, many ASEAN countries, l’central America and Andean Community andUkraine.  I would now like to speak of the last instrument as of the EU's foreign policy: European Neighbourhood Policy. It is now well underway: 12 action plans were adopted. The ministerial conference last week was a success and demonstrated the keen interest of the Member States and our neighbors. We must maintain our momentum and take advantage of the momentum of the Council under the German Presidency to strengthen the offer to our neighbors. I am also proud to have developed the ability toCrisis Managementwithin the Commission and, in particular, DG RELEX. The task is not over but through the Instrument for Stability and better coordination, we are now able to better respond to crisis situations, although much remains to be done, especially in the line drawn by the report Michel Barnier. As regards the implementation of external assistanceWe made at once more, faster and better. This success has been recognized by all donors, most recently during the review by the OECD peers. We replaced most of the old instruments bycoherent set of seven new regulations and today we intensify coordination with other donors, allowing, for example, co-financing of activities.   (2) Our challenges) Looking ahead at the challenges we are facing, what are our priorities? Our immediate priorities are to consolidate the EU’s role as a global actor and tackle some of the most acute security challenges we face.  We must continue work on the EU’s enlargement process and we must continue to develop the European Neighbourhood Policy as an effective tool to support, encourage and monitor political and economic reforms.  Despite its short existence the ENP has already achieved a lot, but we must continue to ensure that the offer we make to our neighbours is as attractive and as relevant as possible. We are driving forward with the Council the agenda we set out last December, and we are pushing in particular for Member States' co operation so that we can make speedy progress on visa facilitation and the establishment of the new Neighbourhood Investment Facility.  Member States and our neighbours clearly recognise the importance of this policy - and voted with their feet at the conference we held in Brussels last week to debate the way forward.  I am confident that as implementation of the action plans deepens, and the differentiation between the participants becomes clearer we will see just how effective a mechanism the ENP can be.  Our relations with Russia will remain of vital strategic interest, as will our efforts through the international Quartet to build peace in the Middle East. Here I expect a lot from the mission of Tony Blair as Special Envoy of the Quartet. We also must contribute to the success of the Middle East conference scheduled for the end of the year.  We must continue our support for building an effective multilateral system in every sphere, from the World Trade Organisation to the United Nations itself. Here are contributions to the WTO work, to the Peace building Commission and more generally our support to the various UN agencies key. The UN SG made it very clear when he visited the Commission earlier this year. There are also three cross-cutting themes which focus our response to the international environment we face and where the Commission has a particular contribution to make: i) The twin challenge of climate change and energy security  The EU has been in the lead in looking to the future and paving the way for a more responsible and more sustainable energy use.   In the run-up to the UN conference in Bali we need to be persuading our partners around the world of the need for similarly ambitious commitments. Your public diplomacy work is decisive. I want you to circulate widely all initiatives and speeches the President, other College members or myself deliver on this issue. More generally, let me insist here on the importance of a pro-active public diplomacy by all of you. As you know, by public diplomacy, we want to reach beyond traditional interlocutors and shape perceptions and opinions of the EU and our policies and values. This is something which must become part of your every day activity.  As for energy security, the external dimension is increasingly important and many of you will have personal experience of the EU’s energy relations with your country. Developing an effective external energy security strategy is now centre stage in our work. The aim is to deepen our partnerships around the globe, with producers, transit countries and consumers, to build co-operation for our mutual benefit.  In the neighbourhood in particular we are deepening our energy partnerships.  We have concluded agreements with Azerbaijan, Morocco and Ukraine, and hope to complete MoUs with Algeria and Egypt before the end of the year.  We are stepping up co operation in Central Asia and aiming for a new agreement with Russia.  ii) Migration I firmly believe that the EU needs a common migration policy. As you know the EU’s migration policy has evolved in the last few years to what we now call the global approach: fighting illegal immigration on the one hand, whilst facilitating legal migration on the other. The key words are here, assistance in border management, conclusion of readmission agreements, promotion of people-to-people contacts by making visa procedures simpler, cheaper and faster. Last May, the Commission has proposed a new system of Mobility Partnerships, which we hope we can pilot with ENP countries. Such partnerships have to cover both, cooperation in combating illegal migration and creating opportunities for access to our Member States’ labour markets such as labour quotas, short stay visas, and practical instruments to match job offers with job seekers. This comes in addition to our focus on the links between migration and development; the brain drain effect and the need to build up economic opportunities in our partner countries. And key to its success will be your skill on the ground in every country - explaining our approach and persuading your countries of their shared responsibility for tackling the challenges posed by migration. iii) Security Preserving the security of European Citizens is our core objective. Security is naturally a broad concept, encompassing Development, political stability and indeed preservation of peace. The Commission has an important contribution to make to any review of the European Security Strategy in the coming year, as proposed by French President Sarkozy two weeks ago. As you know, my concept of security is one of human security, putting individuals rather than states at the heart of our security deliberations. What do I mean by it? It is about bringing together the concerns for the freedom from fear and the freedom from want of people affected by our policies, in particular the most vulnerable ones. This can be achieved for example by empowering people to take their fate in their hands, for which education and more specifically human rights education play an important part. We will soon present a communication on a horizontal security framework in EC external assistance, how to use best instruments like the Stability Instrument for facing security threats and protecting human security. There is an extremely important role for delegations to play here, not only because you have a greater responsibility than in the past for implementation, but also because we rely on you as our eyes and ears on the ground to give us suggestions and spot needs and opportunities for us to become involved. (3 RESPONSE – institutional) But beyond these thematic priorities we also need to focus on making ourselves as fit as possible to meet the big institutional changes that lie ahead. The Commission will give every support to the Portuguese and future Presidencies in meeting the ambitious timetable for the adoption and implementation of the new Treaty. Let us be honest. The ""double-hatted"" role for the new High Representative and Commission Vice President will bring more coherence of EU external action. It will enable the Commission to use its very significant external responsibilities to support of the overall political goals of the EU more effectively.   The mandate for a Reform Treaty also includes setting up a European External Action Service which will support the High Representative in his or her work. I hope talks will start soon on the practicalities of the service. We should take up work where we left off in 2005, when a substantial contribution to the development of the service had already been made. Naturally these changing times make everyone feel a little nervous. But I insist on the message I also sent you last time we met: this is a moment of opportunity, a moment we must grasp with both hands to show that the Commission is a real foreign policy player. We must focus on proving the added value we bring, not directing our efforts towards institutional tugs of war.   We are well placed to do that. The Commission must be at the core of any future EU diplomatic service.  But to guarantee our role we must continue our work of reforming the external service, equipping and training you and your staff to meet the fundamental challenge of your work: managing both the short term and often immediate demands of rapid and effective response to new situations and crises and the long term strategic element of our relations with your host country.  I welcome the progress that has been achieved so far, but I would also stress that the next two years will be crucial in shaping the future and the Commission’s place in it. This is our moment. I gave instruction to Eneko Landaburu to reinforce the training, develop the exchange of staff with Member States and sharpen the ""political profile"" of the delegations. I know that there are some bottlenecks, in particular for the secondment of officials from line DG to the external service. This must be resolved because the external projection of internal EU policies is a priority. I will propose changes if necessary in order to facilitate this secondment.  Before concluding, I would like to emphasize four priorities 1) flexibility We must enhance our ability to deploy our resources and political attention to where they are most needed. A proposal will be considered by theGroup of RELEX Commissionersin October. We clearly consider how to allocate our resources to meet our strategic priorities, both geographic and thematic. Of course, this should not weaken the administrative operation of delegations. We must remain a close administration of the citizens, and in this context, it seemed important to provide opportunities for the Ombudsman to explain his role. 2) real-time communication We need to develop a real-time communication culture. More we engage in the political field, the more important that thereone flux consistand t reciprocalinformation between you and the seat, which gives all the authority of the European Community to your actions. I hope that you strengthen the political profile of the Commission, on the basis of naturally Headquarters clear instructions. I appreciate the improvements in reporting and political analysis I noted in the last two years. But we still have a ways to go to be in the best traditions of European diplomacy. 3) Our relations with the Member States.  The last year's Communication on ""Europe in the world""Reiterated the European consensus for the optimal use of European foreign policy capabilities. We have spent the last year to implement the practical measures he recommended as joint papers and personal exchanges. But more must be done to your level to promote good working relations with representations of Member States, and of course I have in mind allMember States, not just the biggest of them. I'm sure the President will share his position on this point. In my case, I stressed the need to explore ways to share your expertise and analysis with the Member States, including in particular those who are less well represented than others. Of course, this must be reciprocal. 4) The fourth priority, but not least, respect the implementation of external assistance. We have raised expectations in recent years that we must not disappoint. Substantial and increasingly higher funding you are transferred each day. We have our new instruments. We will introduce procedures to start co-financing the implementation of aid. You are leaders on this issue. As new instruments were adopted late and some programming documents remain to be adopted, I count on your effortsduring the next four months to allow implementation of our aid programs as quickly as possible our fiscal rules. It is capital. The objective is also to ensure a more active role in coordination between donors. Here, we must aim to joint reports on progress made by beneficiary countries to cooperate more closely with the EU in the area of ​​the neighborhood or out of poverty in many other regions. Dear colleagues, Your business may be one of the most demanding in the administration today, which makes it both infinitely rewarding and extremely demanding. The changes that will occur as we hope in the foreign service will undoubtedly impose additional challenges. But I am convinced that you are well placed to reap the fruits. It requires us to continue our efforts to become more professional, and have the skills and the most suitable information. Your ideas and suggestions are very valuable and I encourage you to share them with Headquarters. I also have the pleasure to talk with the outgoing officers. Thank you for your attention and happy to answer your questions. Benita
Ferrero-Waldner
Membre de la Commission européenne chargée des relations
extérieures et de la politique européenne de

voisinage

Representing the Union abroad: Key challenges for
the years
ahead
Réunion des chefs de délégation de la Commission

européenne

Bruxelles, le 10 septembre
Mesdames, Messieurs, chers collègues,
Je suis heureuse de vous voir tous ici réunis deux ans après notre
précédente réunion.
Au cours de ces trois dernières années, j'ai eu l'occasion de faire
connaissance avec bon nombre d'entre vous et de me rendre compte de l'excellent
travail que vous effectuez jour après jour. Vous êtes nombreux à

travailler dans des situations très difficiles

: je pense notamment

à

Ilkka Uusitalo

et son équipe, qui doivent faire face à

la menace constante des bombardements à Bagdad, et à

Jan de

Kok

, qui a connu plusieurs jours de couvre-feu à Islamabad en juillet,
pour ne citer que deux d'entre vous. Mais il existe beaucoup d'autres
circonstances dans lesquelles chacun de vous peut connaître des situations
difficiles, pour ne pas dire dangereuses.
Je voudrais aussi prendre un moment pour rendre hommage à nos
collègues qui ont perdu la vie au cours de l'année écoulée.

Je pense, en particulier, à

Alessandro Missir di Lusignano

, de notre

délégation au Maroc, et, le mois dernier encore, à

Jean-Pierre

Pierard

de notre délégation en Nouvelle-Calédonie et à

Michel Gauché

des Fidji.
Chers collègues,

Nous avons maintenant dépassé

la moitié du mandat de la

Commission actuelle

. Aussi, j'aimerais qu'ensemble, nous revenions sur
certaines de nos principales réalisations de ces trois dernières
années, avant de nous intéresser aux défis stratégiques que
nous devons relever et à la façon dont nous allons y répondre
d'un point de vue institutionnel et opérationnel. Le mois prochain, la
présidence portugaise espère mettre la dernière main à un
traité modificatif qui introduira d'importants changements dans notre
sphère de compétence. C’est donc avec un intérêt
particulier que nous pourrons entendre cet après-midi la Présidence,
qui est invitée pour la première fois, à mon initiative, à
participer à notre réunion et qui sera représentée par le
secrétaire d'État aux affaires européennes Lobo Antunes cet
après-midi.
(1- Nos réalisations)

J'aimerais tout d'abord rappeler certaines de nos réalisations

.

Nous avons dû faire face à un certain nombre de

défis

extrêmement exigeants et imprévisibles

; depuis les catastrophes
naturelles, comme le tsunami de décembre 2004 et le récent
tremblement de terre au Pérou, jusqu'aux crises politiques. Je pense

notamment à la nécessité de mettre en place un

mécanisme

international temporaire, le ""TIM"",

pour acheminer notre aide vers les

Territoires palestiniens. Je pense aussi à la gestion de la

crise

libanaise

en juillet de l'année dernière. La libération du

personnel médical détenu en

Libye

a également
constitué une grande réussite pour l'UE et, de fait, pour la
Commission. A cet égard, j'aimerais d'ailleurs saisir cette occasion pour

exprimer toute ma gratitude à

Marc Pierini

.

Ces divers défis ont tous été

gérés de façon

exceptionnelle

, ce qui a permis de renforcer la réputation grandissante
de la Commission pour ce qui est de l'efficacité de ses réactions dans
les situations de crise. Nous devons, en effet, être à même de
réagir rapidement sous des contraintes temporelles et politiques

extrêmes. Mais

nous devons aussi

défendre nos

intérêts stratégiques

. C'est pourquoi nous avons aussi
continué de renforcer nos relations stratégiques avec les principaux

acteurs de la scène internationale.

Avec pour résultat

,
notamment, une stratégie renouvelée en ce qui concerne la

Chine

, à qui nous avons proposé de développer un
partenariat plus étroit mais aussi d'assumer davantage de
responsabilités.

Quant aux

États-Unis

, les anciens nuages qui ont pu assombrir
notre relation se sont largement dissipés et nous continuons de construire
l'indispensable partenariat qui nous lie à ce pays. Ce partenariat sera
encore renforcé par le nouveau Conseil économique transatlantique que
nous avons lancé cette année en vue de réduire les contraintes
réglementaires. Nous travaillons en parallèle sur les questions
politiques et de sécurité qui concernent les principales régions
en crise du monde entier, et je pense que nous sommes, de plus en plus,
véritablement perçus par Washington comme un acteur qui compte.   Nous

dialoguons en permanence avec notre voisin la

Russie

sur les sujets les
plus divers. Le partenariat doit être développé, et nous faisons
le maximum pour y parvenir, mais nous avons également besoin du soutien de
Moscou.
Le sommet de Vienne de mai 2006 a débouché sur un programme de

travail ambitieux avec l’

Amérique latine

et le tout premier

sommet organisé entre l’UE et le

Brésil

a confirmé
le statut de «partenaire stratégique» de ce pays. Il en va de

même avec l’

Afrique du Sud

, qui a également rejoint ce
club exclusif des «partenaires stratégiques».  Nous avons

renforcé le pilier politique de notre partenariat avec le

Japon

.

Dernier pays et non des moindres, l’

Inde

: Nous mettons
aujourd’hui en œuvre le plan d’action ambitieux adopté il
y a deux ans. Parallèlement à ces partenariats stratégiques, nous

avons conclu un nouveau partenariat avec l’

Asie centrale

et nous
avons ouvert des négociations en vue de nouveaux accords de partenariat et

de coopération avec la

Chine

, plusieurs

pays de l'ASEAN

,

l’

Amérique centrale

et la

Communauté andine

et

l’

Ukraine

.
Je voudrais à présent parler du dernier instrument en date de la

politique étrangère de l’UE: la

politique européenne de

voisinage

. Elle est désormais bien engagée: 12 plans
d’action ont été adoptés. La conférence
ministérielle de la semaine dernière a été un succès et
a montré le vif intérêt des États membres et de nos voisins.
Nous devons poursuivre sur notre lancée et profiter de la dynamique
insufflée par le Conseil sous la présidence allemande pour renforcer
l’offre proposée à nos voisins. Je suis également

fière d’avoir pu développer la capacité de

gestion des

crises

au sein de la Commission et, en particulier, de la DG RELEX. La
tâche n'est pas terminée mais grâce à l'instrument de
stabilité et à une meilleure coordination, nous sommes désormais
en mesure de mieux répondre aux situations de crise, même si beaucoup
reste à faire, notamment dans la ligne tracée par le rapport de Michel
Barnier.

En ce qui concerne la

mise en œuvre de l’aide

extérieure

, nous avons fait tout à la fois plus, plus vite et
mieux. Cette réussite a été reconnue par l’ensemble des
donateurs, et tout dernièrement lors de l’examen par les pairs de
l'OCDE. Nous avons remplacé la plupart des anciens instruments par un

ensemble cohérent de sept nouveaux règlements

et nous
intensifions aujourd’hui la coordination avec d’autres donateurs, en
permettant, par exemple, le cofinancement d’activités.
(2) Our challenges)

Looking ahead at the challenges we are facing,

what are our

priorities

?

Our immediate priorities are to

consolidate the EU’s role as a

global actor

and tackle some of the most acute security challenges we face.
We must continue work on the EU’s enlargement process and we must continue

to

develop the European Neighbourhood Policy

as an effective tool to
support, encourage and monitor political and economic reforms.  Despite its
short existence the ENP has already achieved a lot, but we must continue to
ensure that the offer we make to our neighbours is as attractive and as relevant
as possible. We are driving forward with the Council the agenda we set out last
December, and we are pushing in particular for Member States' co operation so
that we can make speedy progress on visa facilitation and the establishment of

the new

Neighbourhood Investment Facility

. Member States and our
neighbours clearly recognise the importance of this policy - and voted with
their feet at the conference we held in Brussels last week to debate the way
forward.  I am confident that as implementation of the action plans deepens, and
the differentiation between the participants becomes clearer we will see just
how effective a mechanism the ENP can be.

Our relations with

Russia

will remain of vital strategic interest, as
will our efforts through the international Quartet to build peace in the

Middle East

. Here I expect a lot from the mission of

Tony Blair

as
Special Envoy of the Quartet. We also must contribute to the success of the
Middle East conference scheduled for the end of the year.

We must continue our support for building an

effective multilateral

system

in every sphere, from the World Trade Organisation to the United
Nations itself. Here are contributions to the WTO work, to the Peace building
Commission and more generally our support to the various UN agencies key. The UN
SG made it very clear when he visited the Commission earlier this year.

There are also three

cross-cutting themes

which focus our response to
the international environment we face and where the Commission has a particular
contribution to make:

i

) The twin challenge of climate change and energy security
The EU has been in the lead in looking to the future and paving the way for a
more responsible and more sustainable energy use.

In the run-up to the

UN conference in Bali

we need to be persuading
our partners around the world of the need for similarly ambitious commitments.
Your public diplomacy work is decisive. I want you to circulate widely all
initiatives and speeches the President, other College members or myself deliver
on this issue. More generally, let me insist here on the importance of a

pro-active public diplomacy

by all of you. As you know, by public
diplomacy, we want to reach beyond traditional interlocutors and shape
perceptions and opinions of the EU and our policies and values. This is
something which must become part of your every day activity.

As for

energy security

, the external dimension is increasingly
important and many of you will have personal experience of the EU’s energy
relations with your country. Developing an effective external energy security
strategy is now centre stage in our work. The aim is to deepen our partnerships
around the globe, with producers, transit countries and consumers, to build

co-operation for our mutual benefit.

In the neighbourhood

in particular
we are deepening our energy partnerships.  We have concluded agreements with
Azerbaijan, Morocco and Ukraine, and hope to complete MoUs with Algeria and
Egypt before the end of the year.  We are stepping up co operation in Central
Asia and aiming for a new agreement with Russia.

ii)

Migration

I firmly believe that

the EU needs a common migration policy

. As you
know the EU’s migration policy has evolved in the last few years to what

we now call the global approach: fighting

illegal

immigration on the one

hand, whilst facilitating

legal

migration on the other. The

key

words

are here, assistance in

border management

, conclusion of

readmission agreements

,

promotion of people-to-people contacts

by
making visa procedures simpler, cheaper and faster.

Last May, the Commission has proposed a new system of

Mobility

Partnerships

, which we hope we can pilot with ENP countries. Such
partnerships have to cover both, cooperation in combating illegal migration

and

creating opportunities for access to our Member States’ labour
markets such as labour quotas, short stay visas, and practical instruments to
match job offers with job seekers. This comes in addition to our focus on the
links between migration and development; the brain drain effect and the need to
build up economic opportunities in our partner countries.
And key to its success will be your skill on the ground in every country -
explaining our approach and persuading your countries of their shared
responsibility for tackling the challenges posed by migration.
iii) Security

Preserving the security of European Citizens is our core objective

.
Security is naturally a broad concept, encompassing Development, political
stability and indeed preservation of peace. The Commission has an important
contribution to make to any review of the European Security Strategy in the
coming year, as proposed by French President Sarkozy two weeks ago.

As you know, my concept of security is one of

human

security

,
putting individuals rather than states at the heart of our security
deliberations. What do I mean by it? It is about bringing together the concerns
for the freedom from fear and the freedom from want of people affected by our
policies, in particular the most vulnerable ones. This can be achieved for
example by empowering people to take their fate in their hands, for which
education and more specifically human rights education play an important part.
We will soon present a communication on a horizontal security framework in EC

external assistance, how to

use best instruments like the Stability

Instrument

for facing security threats and protecting human security.
There is an extremely important role for delegations to play here, not only
because you have a greater responsibility than in the past for implementation,
but also because we rely on you as our eyes and ears on the ground to give us
suggestions and spot needs and opportunities for us to become involved.
(3 RESPONSE – institutional)
But beyond these thematic priorities we also need to focus on making

ourselves as fit as possible to meet

the big institutional changes that lie

ahead

. The Commission will give every support to the Portuguese and future
Presidencies in meeting the ambitious timetable for the adoption and
implementation of the new Treaty.
Let us be honest. The ""double-hatted"" role for the new High Representative

and Commission Vice President will

bring more coherence of EU external

action

. It will enable the Commission to use its very significant external
responsibilities to support of the overall political goals of the EU more
effectively.

The mandate for a Reform Treaty also includes setting up a

European

External Action Service

which will support the High Representative in his or
her work. I hope talks will start soon on the practicalities of the service. We
should take up work where we left off in 2005, when a substantial contribution
to the development of the service had already been made.
Naturally these changing times make everyone feel a little nervous. But I
insist on the message I also sent you last time we met: this is a moment of

opportunity, a moment we must grasp with both hands to

show that the

Commission is a real foreign policy player

. We must focus on proving the
added value we bring, not directing our efforts towards institutional tugs of
war.

We are well placed to do that.

The Commission must be at the core of
any future EU diplomatic service.

But to guarantee our role

we must continue our work of reforming the

external service

, equipping and training you and your staff to meet the

fundamental challenge of your work: managing

both

the

short term
and often immediate demands of rapid and effective response to new situations

and crises and the

long term

strategic element of our relations with your
host country.
I welcome the progress that has been achieved so far, but I would also stress

that

the next two years will be crucial in shaping the future and the

Commission’s place in it

. This is our moment. I gave instruction to

Eneko Landaburu to

reinforce the training

,

develop the exchange of

staff with Member States

and

sharpen the ""political profile

"" of the
delegations. I know that there are some bottlenecks, in particular for the
secondment of officials from line DG to the external service. This must be
resolved because the external projection of internal EU policies is a priority.
I will propose changes if necessary in order to facilitate this secondment.

Avant de terminer, je voudrais mettre l'accent sur

quatre
priorités
1) la flexibilité

Nous devons

accroître notre capacité de déployer nos
ressources et notre attention politique là où elles sont les plus

nécessaires

. Une proposition sera examinée par le

Groupe des

Commissaires RELEX

au mois d'octobre. Nous examinerons clairement comment
allouer nos ressources afin de répondre à nos priorités
stratégiques, tant géographiques que thématiques. Bien sûr,
ceci ne doit pas affaiblir le fonctionnement administratif des
délégations. Nous devons demeurer une administration proche des
citoyens, et dans ce contexte, il m’a semblé important de donner la
possibilité à l'ombudsman de vous expliquer son rôle.
2) la communication en temps réel
Nous devons développer une culture de communication en temps réel.
Plus nous nous engageons sur le terrain politique, plus il est important qu'il y

ait

un flux constan

t et

réciproque

d'informations entre vous
et le Siège, qui donne toute l'autorité de la Communauté
européenne à vos actions. Je souhaite que vous renforciez le profil
politique de la Commission, naturellement sur la base d'instructions claires du
Siège.
J'apprécie les améliorations dans le reporting et l'analyse
politiques que j'ai notées ces deux dernières années. Mais nous
avons encore du chemin à faire pour être au niveau des meilleures
traditions de la diplomatie européenne.
3) Nos relations avec les Etats membres.

La Communication de l'an dernier sur l’ ""

Europe dans le monde

"" a
renouvelé le consensus européen en faveur d'une utilisation optimale
des capacités de politique étrangère européenne. Nous avons
consacré l'année dernière à mettre en œuvre les mesures
pratiques qu'il recommandait, comme les papiers conjoints et les échanges

de personnels. Mais

davantage doit être fait à votre niveau
pour promouvoir de bonnes relations de travail avec les représentations des

Etats membres, et j'ai bien sûr à l'esprit

tous

les Etats
membres, pas simplement les plus grands d'entre eux. Je suis sûre que la
Présidence nous fera part de sa position sur ce point. En ce qui me
concerne, j'insiste sur la nécessité d'explorer les moyens de partager
votre expertise et vos analyses avec les Etats membres, y compris et notamment
ceux qui sont moins largement représentés que d'autres. Bien sûr,
ceci doit être à réciproque.

4) La quatrième priorité, mais non des moindres, concerne

la

mise en œuvre de l'assistance extérieure

. Nous avons fait
naître des attentes ces dernières années que nous ne devons pas
décevoir. Des financements substantiels et toujours plus élevés
vous sont transférés chaque jour. Nous avons nos nouveaux instruments.
Nous allons introduire les procédures permettant de commencer le
cofinancement de la mise en œuvre de l'aide. Vous êtes chefs de file
sur ce dossier.
Comme les nouveaux instruments ont été adoptés tard et que

certains documents de programmation doivent encore être adoptés,

je

compte sur vos efforts

durant les quatre mois à venir pour permettre
une mise en œuvre de nos programmes d'aides aussi rapidement que le
permettent nos règles budgétaires. C'est capital.
L’objectif sera aussi d'assurer un rôle plus actif dans la

coordination entre bailleurs

. Ici, nous devons viser à des rapports
conjoints sur les progrès réalisés par les pays
bénéficiaires pour coopérer plus étroitement avec l'UE dans
la zone du voisinage ou pour sortir de la pauvreté dans bien d'autres
régions du globe.
Chers collègues,
Votre métier est peut-être l'un des plus exigeants dans
l'administration d'aujourd'hui, ce qui le rend à la fois infiniment
gratifiant et extrêmement exigeant. Les changements qui s'opéreront
comme nous l'espérons dans le service extérieur vont sans nul doute
imposer des défis supplémentaires. Mais je suis convaincue que vous
êtes bien placés pour en tirer les fruits. Il nous faut pour cela
continuer nos efforts pour devenir encore plus professionnels, et disposer des
compétences et des informations les plus adaptées. Vos idées et
suggestions sont très précieuses et je vous encourage à les
partager avec le Siège. J'aurai aussi le plaisir d'en discuter avec le
bureau sortant.
Je vous remercie pour votre attention et réponds volontiers à vos
éventuelles questions.

José Manuel Durão Barroso President of the European Commission Speech on the results of the European Council of 21-23 June 2007 European Parliament Plenary Brussels, 27 June 2007,27-06-2007,European Commission,European Commission,1530," SPEECH/07/435 José Manuel Barroso President of the European CommissionSpeech on the results of the European Council of 21-23 June 2007 European Parliament PlenaryBrussels, 27 June 2007 Ladies and Gentlemen, Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, allow me, that I mean to / recognition for the performance of Chancellor Angela Merkel utter here! A very difficult task resulted in a success for Europe. In particular, I would like to acknowledge the political ambition that led the Chancellor to insist on a reform / contract which gives the Union the right tools in hand, to face the challenges of the 21st (twenty-first) century. Chancellor Merkel and the entire team of the German Council / presidential deserves the highest value / estimate for their tough struggle for the objectives and for their ability to get the negotiations to a successful end on / right. This compliment refers not only to the result of the June Council, but on the total number of achievements of the German Presidency throughout the semester. The success of the twin-track approach Let me step back from the events of the last week and look back over the last two years. Just over a year ago the Commission adopted an approach which I called the twin track approach. The first track was for the EU to use the existing Treaties more effectively to deliver results for Europe's citizens. This we have done, for example through our package of measures on energy and climate change, through our focus on innovation, through our drive against red tape, through legislation which delivers benefits for consumers – such as on roaming. I want to thank this House for its support on many of these initiatives. The second track was to return to the process of Treaty reform. The first step was the Berlin Declaration and we concluded the second step last Friday. In short, what the Commission has proposed is what has happened. Why? Because the twin track approach is the right approach. Governments and citizens have the confidence to tackle institutional issues if they have the confidence in the institutions to deliver on their concerns; growth and jobs, and also the new agenda – such as energy, climate change and security. The recent Eurobarometer is encouraging: the support for EU membership and the perceived benefits of membership have considerably improved during the last two years. And 69% of Europeans say they are fairly optimistic with regards to the future of the European Union. Results of the European Council Let me be very frank: the results of the European Council are excellent. Today, in this House, it is the moment to stress this point. We started from a division between 18 Member States that had ratified the Constitutional Treaty and 9 Member States that had not ratified. We have now all 27 Member States united around a common mandate for a Reform Treaty. The fact that we managed an agreement is already an outstanding political result and we should be grateful for the willingness of all governments to compromise. Now, we should look forward to the ratification process in 2008-09 as a great moment of solidarity and unity in Europe, and as a historical opportunity to consolidate the enlarged European Union. At the same time, the advances from the Nice Treaty will guarantee a Union with a greater capacity to act, to deliver results. a) EU's capacity to act Before the European Council, I said that the need to reinforce the European Union's capacity to act is a crucial reason to defend a new Treaty. The Reform Treaty will bring important advances to the Union and will reinforce its ability to act. First of all, the Union will be fully consolidated by overcoming the pillar structure and by acquiring single personality. Then, I would like to stress, in particular, three areas: First, the most substantial advances are in the area of justice and home affairs. The more than 40 new cases of Qualified Majority Voting in the Reform Treaty include external borders control, asylum, immigration, criminal law and police cooperation. The Treaty will also fully integrate these areas in the Community method of decision-making. It is, in fact, the communitarisation of the Third Pillar. This is a fundamental reform, which will create a true space of freedom, security and justice in Europe, and it will be a priority for the rest of the mandate of this Commission. The Union needs the efficiency which more QMV brings. It is no use having the right policies if they are agreed years too late. Second, the Reform Treaty will offer new possibilities and reinforced legal bases to deal with the challenges of energy policy and climate change. In particular, the Commission is very pleased with the solidarity clause on energy security, and the agreement to add combating climate change to the Treaty. Energy security and climate change are now core priorities for the Union: it is right that this is reflected in the Treaties. Third, the Reform Treaty will reinforce the Union's cohesion in external affairs. In the 21st world, it is only by combining the forces of our Member States and of our institutions that we can compete with other leading great powers. Our prosperity, our freedom, and our security depend on the capacity to compete at the global level. Europe will, increasingly, speak with one voice in diplomatic, security and defence issues, in trade, in humanitarian aid, and in development, and as such will be better equipped to defend our values and interests in world politics. We will have the conditions and the instruments to shape globalization, and we cannot miss such a historical opportunity. b) More accountability and democratic legitimacy With the Reform Treaty, the Union will also reinforce its accountability and its democratic legitimacy. Again, let me emphasise three cases of clear improvement, compared to the Nice Treaty. First, the European Parliament will have greater participation in the legislative process of the Union, by an increase in co-decision procedures. With the new Treaty, the vast majority of European laws will be adopted jointly by the European Parliament and by the Council. Second, national parliaments will be more involved in the workings of the Union. The new Treaty will amend the protocol on subsidiarity and proportionality. This Commission has always welcomed a greater role of national parliaments. However, the Commission also made clear that involving national parliaments in the control of subsidiarity should not undermine the essentials of how the EU works. First, any new procedure on subsidiarity would have to respect the Community method and the right of initiative of the Commission. Secondly, the European Parliament and the Council should be on an equal footing. Finally, the thresholds regarding majorities should rise to reflect the importance of the procedure. We managed to secure all our demands and as such to preserve the institutional balance of the Union, while reinforcing the control of subsidiarity. Third, the Reform Treaty will give legal force to the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The fact that the Charter is legally binding is a powerful symbol of the strong ties between the Union and European citizens. The Charter will be a safeguard both for European citizens and for national institutions, and will be a central part of the system of checks and balances in our Union of law. The preservation of the acquis in the Single Market. I have always said that a step back from the existing ""acquis"" would be unacceptable. This is particularly important in respect of the Single Market. The results of the European Council were entirely positive from the Commission perspective. The protocols on services of general interest and on internal market and competition, both proposed by the Commission, guarantee a fair and undistorted functioning of the Single Market, while respecting legitimate concerns of some Member States. Before concluding, let me warn against the temptation of a ""perverse alliance"" between those who resist to a political Europe and those who oppose the Single Market. To those who support an open and a global Europe, I say that they will only get it if they support political integration. Without political power, Europe will never influence globalization. And to those who want a strong political Europe, I say that they will only get it if they support the Single Market and economic integration. We cannot defend the European project by attacking the Single Market. The way ahead After the success of the European Council, we have two crucial stages ahead. First, we need to finalise the IGC and to sign the Reform Treaty. The IGC will start next month and the Portuguese Presidency aims to conclude in October. I fully support this. Then, Member States need to ratify the Treaty. Meanwhile, we need to explain the European public why this Treaty will be a necessary and positive step forward. Such a narrative will be a central part of the Commission opinion ahead of the IGC. I also know that this House is already working hard on its opinion. I certainly hope that the European Parliament and the Commission can continue to work closely on spreading the message that this reform is indispensable to meet the challenges of the 21st century and to deliver better results to European citizens: the real winners of the Reform Treaty.
